urn:contentItem:5XNS-8F01-F0JS-Y2NJ-00000-00Changing China Is Opening Up For Health Care Entrants2019-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisChanging China Is Opening Up For Health Care Entrants

The barriers for health care industry entrants into China are lowering, but still not as quickly as many medtech companies would like. Recent structural health care delivery plans are instilling more confidence in a market and industry that in the past have been regarded with suspicion. Much of the change is down to the new climate for business being overseen by PRC president Xi Jinping. Global law firm CMS' China expert Nick Beckett explained what is changing and why western companies should monitor developments.

Of the four Chinese companies that feature in In Vivo's Top 100 medical device companies by revenues for 2018 (Lepu Medical Technology (Beijing) Co. Ltd., cardiovascular products and services, Beijing;   MicroPort Scientific Corp., orthopedic and cardiac products, Shanghai; Jiangsu Yuyue Medical Equipment & Supply, Zhenjiang; and Shinva Medical Instrument Co., Shandong), only Shinva, a sterilization and disinfection equipment manufacturer, is in the top 50 of global medtech companies by US dollar-ranked revenues.

Chinese manufacturers are under-represented at this level, and so are foreign companies and their medtech innovations in China. But China is changing as demand is growing for the technologies that western patients already have access to. Changing attitudes about the value of health care will help transform China's health care industry and market in the decade ahead. Mindful of the need for quality health care for the vast local population, Chinese decision makers, from Jinping down, are overseeing an ongoing process of support and investment in the sector.

The overall framework is set out in the 13th Five-Year Plan for economic and social development of the People's Republic of China 2016-2020, listing China's strategic intentions and major objectives, tasks, and measures for economic and social development. By the end of the plan, for a national population anticipated to reach 1.42 billion in 2020, the major aims are for: China's GDP and per capita personal income to have doubled from 2010 levels; industrial production to have moved towards the medium-high end; and for visible outcomes of the support being given to foster innovation-driven development, business start-ups and internationally-competitive enterprises.

In a section dedicated to promoting a healthy China, the Plan promises deepened reform of the health care system, an emphasis on prevention, and strategies to control of chronic diseases  ̶  cardiovascular, brain, and vascular diseases, diabetes, cancer, respiratory disease, and mental illness. It speaks of a tiered medical diagnosis and treatment system and general practitioner capacity improvements, with the number of active physicians targeted to reach 2.5 per 1,000 people.

Enlarging the scale of the national health industry, and perfecting the health care services systems, are two of the five specific goals of Healthy China 2030: A Vision for Health Care, released in October 2016 by Jinping as a blueprint for the changes China should make in the coming decade. With innovation at its center, it advocates a role for market mechanisms, and recommends, in 29 chapters, 13 indicators and four core principles, how China must factor in reform in key areas, including in the areas of public health services, food and drug safety and the Chinese medical industry.

The ground is increasingly fertile and the population ready for the health care reforms and delivery improvements of the kinds detailed in these two reports. That is the view of CMS' Nick Beckett, the law firm's co-head of life sciences and health care, and head of Asia-Pacific IP, who spends much of his time in Beijing and greater China. Speaking to In Vivo, he observed that, in health care, China is indeed at a turning point. The markets may have heard that before, but the sense now is of real change to come.            

One reason for increased optimism that China is more ready now to turn the corner is that the youth of the country, more connected through social media, international travel and foreign education and experiences, have a greater awareness of what goes on beyond China. Other parts of the world have access to innovative devices and drugs, and China's millennials are now demanding them too. Overseas companies are monitoring this, factoring in the impact it will have. Beckett observed that these companies will need to be more patient - and consumer - focused, and ready to bring their technologies, new or yet-to-be-developed, into China to provide information and support local patients.

This comes at the same time that AI, machine learning and the advantages offered by big data - a major focus in the Five-Year Plan 2016-2020 ̶  are being brought to bear. For health care, AI is seen as a transformational step, and the next few years will be truly fascinating in terms of who will drive developments in the digital health care ecosystem. China is a global leader in AI, alongside the UK and US. Its homegrown major tech groups, Tencent and Alibaba especially, continue to make huge strides in digital health care delivery. In some ways, the traditional big pharma companies, especially, seem to be relatively unprepared  ̶ a surprise, given the accelerated pace of developments over the past four to five years.

The uptake of AI in China is one of the focus areas of a CMS "legal perspectives" document, "AI in Life Sciences," which quotes a government prediction of the value of the Chinese AI industry in 2025: RMB400bn, according to the national "Plan for the Development of a New Generation of AI." The slight puzzle, still, is that pharma and to an extent medtech too, while talking up the prospects of AI, are still grappling with the hows and whys in terms of monetizing it and bringing it into business models. They more often talk about specific bolt-ons only, but by contrast, China's Tencent, for one, is not waiting around (see below).

Awareness Of Health Care On The Up

The sense that China is ready to open up for health care entrants is boosted by the knowledge that while the population has traditionally had a low fundamental awareness of health, greater awareness of that very fact means that remedial action is unavoidable. The millennial generation's attitudes will be a contributory factor to the speed of change ahead.

Historically, as a very poor country, China has lacked a health care infrastructure. No or low primary care availability and no local GP interface have forced patients to head off to usually crowded hospitals to seek an appointment. With no yardstick about their ailment, patients have been prone to overreact to very simple issues, and so there remain big challenges around educational issues, and about patients being able to seek appropriate health care attention for perhaps minor health issues. Here is an area where awareness, from an albeit low base, is set to rise markedly.

Coupled with that, China's new vision of itself as a "strong and growing country" in turn fosters notions that it should rightfully have good health care. That is still not the case in the large rural areas, but there, too, a better basic understanding of health is developing. The advent of technology, and personal health care information apps that give basic information about conditions, are facilitating and driving that.

In view of this, medtech companies should be providing support to those patients who are more receptive to it and maybe even more demanding of it. This will lead to demands for better basic health care provision. Healthy China 2030 and its recommendations are central tenets of the administration, which now finds it must provide in the large rural communities the standard of health care enjoyed by the slightly more affluent people in Shanghai or Beijing, say. "The government had to up its game in terms of quality of health care services, and, tied to the opening up of the market to private investment, it's apparent that it is all coming together," said Beckett.

One China

China's policies are built around a "one country" approach for health care, and good provision across the provinces and into the remote rural zones. The use of remote monitoring technology, such as telecare/telemedicine systems, is seen as increasingly critical in rural China. Allowing private investment is one of the strategies to develop health care provision in China's the second and third-tier cites.

While China can "move at the speed of light" for building projects, etc., in policy, law and regulation it sometimes moves much more slowly

The Five-Year Plan underlines the "one country, two systems," approaches for Hong Kong and Macao. Hong Kong's current protests against its government over China's drive for more influence there are being watched closely for potential effects on business. China also seeks to build cross-Straits cooperation with Taiwan, under the One China approach.

Private health care, although still very small-scale, has been making inroads in China in the past three to five years, manifesting itself in the establishment of specialist clinics for respiratory disease, for example. "The ground work has been done to allow greater investment now in both private and public private hospitals," said Beckett, adding however, that while China can "move at the speed of light" for building projects, etc, in policy, law and regulation it sometimes moves much more slowly.

Pilot Zones

Using pilot zones is a common approach of the Chinese authorities. A prime example in summer 2019 was the way it tested the new marketing authorization holder (MAA) tool for medtech. The MAH is a very significant concept that until recently did not exist in China. Medtech product license owners were typically the manufacturers, and only they could own the MA, and could only transfer it to another manufacturer.

This led to difficulties, with so much economic activity tied to manufacturing capability. The MAH system, first used in three zones, then in a further 21 this year, makes matters much easier and will lead to contracts being set up in manufacturing development. CROs and CSOs etc are expected to flourish in what will become a wider outsourcing environment.

But such processes often take several years, as the Chinese need to be totally comfortable before rolling out their scheme nationwide.

The medtech MAH rule is also seen as a boost for local innovation. "It will be a move from basic and mid-level devices, to higher-end and probably higher-price devices, and thereby will help Chinese commercial operators be better able to compete globally," said Beckett.

Jinping's "One belt one road" trade outreach project focuses on improving connectivity and cooperation across Asia, Africa and Europe. Though not primarily a tool for medtech projects, if China were to develop large medtech champions, they too could use the OBOR to develop trading routes and find trading partners, eventually helping their global health care trading plans.

Slow China  

Critics would argue that "eventually" has too often been a signature word for Chinese policy initiatives. The long-awaited amendment to the PRC Drug Administration Law came into effect on 1 December 2019. It is a second major systematic and structural amendment to China's drug-administration framework since the implementation of the last significant amendment in 2001. But the amendment has been in the works since 2015.

The catalyst was the China's State Council's issuance in October 2017 of the Opinions on Deepening Regulatory Reforms to Encourage Drug and Medical Device Innovation. This proposed fundamental changes to regulatory systems, including the simplification of clinical trials, implementing the Drug Marketing Administration Holder (MAH) system, establishing a patent-linkage regime and perfecting the drug-registration process. The MAH system for medtech is slowly and carefully coming into place now.

"Politically, China tries to do things in such a way to get everyone on side with it; not to do anything suddenly," Beckett observed. A frustration is that several of China's regulatory authorities are often involved in looking at the same issues at the same time (three were studying China's anti-trust and competition law), which does not make for swift passage of regulatory instruments.

In the medtech domain, the NMPA (National Medical Products Administration), the Chinese agency for regulating drugs and medical devices, has been mulling the dropping of the country of origin (COO) certification requirement for "priority" devices that qualify for its "Green Channel," fast-track innovation approval pathway. But nervousness of making big decisions among individual regulatory executives has led to a situation where no decision has yet been taken. The culture is such that regulatory officers would rather not make a decision than make a wrong decision. In terms of the COO, the nervousness is at individual level, not at a state level. "Looking at it through the lens of the Chinese state, it's clear China's not in a hurry, I feel," said Beckett.

The Green channel, the fast-track system for both innovative and priority devices, has not so far been called into action as much as had been anticipated. It was set up in 2014, but five years on, use of this route to expedite devices remains underused by manufacturers. The consensus is that the initiative has value, however. And on the regulator's side, it is a sign of preparedness to expedite the right products, Beckett noted. From a western company's perspective, as an initiative, it ties in with foreign clinical trials exemptions, quicker regulatory reviews, and products getting to market much faster, and indeed, coming to market first.

The regulations and infrastructure being put in place now in China are more internationally aligned and are more acceptable to companies in the west

Reaching Out

The regulations and infrastructure being put in place now in China are more internationally aligned, and so are more acceptable to companies in the west, which are no longer worried quite so much about each and every step they take. In the area of IP, China has formalized dialog with US judges, the UK and Japan, which is also making China more internationally accepted. "The lens is slowly changing, and we may soon have data exclusivity and a patent linkage system. "We already have patent recognition and special courts protecting companies' rights," said Beckett.

The standards are changing, and the infrastructure is being put in place that allows investors in China to have more confidence. From China's perspective, there is a drive to elevate domestic life sciences companies to "national champion level," so that they can eventually compete globally. However, although there is a long way to go in the life sciences and health care spaces, where there are outstanding learning requirements, and the ongoing need for talent and know how. This makes China receptive to foreign investment and assistance in ways which, other industries, for example telecoms, simply do not need.

The recent development in the Drug Administration Law (see above) also answers in some ways the need in China to align more with international standards. The authorities are looking at bringing in a pharmacovigilance standard, and are changing the emphasis from pre-approval to more post-approval. The pre-approval stage in pharma is much faster now, enabling companies to bring products to market more swiftly, but at the same time, with increasing liabilities on them. China is on the same basic path in devices, making strides in exemptions from local clinical trials. "It all fits," said Beckett.

Clearly, China is more prepared to use a mix of international and Chinese standards in its regulatory infrastructure. It is developing its own UDI system for medical devices, but using ISO-based, China-specific standards, GB (the code for national standards, issued by the Standards Administration) and YY (the  code for medical devices, issued by the NMPA). The medtech industry follows both sets of standards, says Chao Xu, co-founder of Chinese consultancy J-Medtec (Berlin, Germany).

Imitation To Achieve Greater Goals

"China is not afraid to copy - historically seen as a high form of flattery in China," said Beckett. The law, for example, is very heavily based on European law, and the patent linkage system is partially derived from the US system.

The same principle applies in the case of WeChat, the multi-purpose messaging, social media and mobile payment app, owned by Tencent Holdings. Tencent specializes in internet-related services and products, has become bigger than the concept it imitated, Facebook, and is increasingly important in digital health care. It was the first Chinese firm to have a market valuation of over $500bn. Of the three big tech players in China, including Alibaba and Baidu, Tencent is the fastest growing in health care.

Tencent Trusted Doctor now claims to connect 440,000 certified doctors with more than 10 million patients online. It collaborates with Germany's Merck KGaA, and it also operates WeDoctor, a web-appointments, education, diagnosis, and consultation tool. Alibaba is developing services to support China's primary care system through online doctor consultations.

Primary Care Issue To Be Solved

Such tools are gaining a lot of ground in the relative absence of primary care in China, where there are some very early-stage plans to install primary care services in hospitals and a push to establish smaller clinics that integrate technology.

At the same time, China sees the need to increase the standing and social status of general practitioners, who believe they are perceived as inferior to specialists. A 2017 survey by the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and others revealed that Chinese physicians bear heavy physical, mental, and financial stress. Low confidence, trust and respect in them from wider society are some of their other complaints. Soberingly, over 70% would not encourage their children to follow their career path.

Talent Being Brought In

China is encouraging foreign talent into the country, including in Nanjing, the heart of the Chinese pharma industry, to leverage the knowledge to innovate and help advance the local industry. Nanjing University is a leading university in the pharmaceutical field in China. The country is welcoming new, innovative products in the life sciences domain, but it will ensure that it retains the firm hand of control over any decisions.

Another tool for developing health care and local health care business is the special zones, such as Hainan province, where the aim is to create a free trade zone and medical tourist pilot zone. It would be able to take advantage of its position to maximize the huge trading potential with Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand, among others.

The changing environment under Jinping has also seen a big push to rid the country of corruption at all levels over the past five or six years. The historical problem with corruption partly lies in the multiple layers of distributors, and the power of money. The GSK kickbacks episode and 2014 judgement scared companies and individuals alike, and everyone redoubled compliance and auditing activities, set up proper local training, and reviewed their procedures.

But the involvement of third parties still presents challenges, as it means manufacturers losing sight of what happens and possibly losing control. The government has tightened up this whole area by reducing distributor numbers, slimming down brands, introducing invoice controls, and generally tidying up the system. "It was built in, and changing it has been a big challenge, but Xi Jinping has taken strong action and it's now a lot better than it was," said Beckett.

The tariff issues between the US and China have done nothing to help China's global trade ambitions, but the effects are being seen in the US too, where providers are having to consider finding alternative sources for Chinese imported devices. VC funding has been impacted recently by the US trade tensions, after a big VC funding uptake in 2018.

Strategic Signposts Point To More Health care

The Five-Year Plan and Healthy China 2030 initiative are strategic signposts for massive change, and a strong indication of where China is focusing.

They acknowledge that Chinese role model names in medtech and pharma are not there as yet, and at present, aspiring innovators in China are looking at companies like Johnson & Johnson as models to emulate.

They underline the critical nature of partnerships to success in China.  And they encourage companies to "be the first in China," under the package of measures being developed for the health care products industries. China has not yet featured in the launch strategies of global companies at an early stage: it used to be at the very end of such plans. Now, it's getting to a point where companies might consider to launch in China first. "But it's very early days there, and that notion needs more time," said Beckett.

Locally, investment is being improved, as seen, for example, in the new health care incubator fund in Shenzen, in the Greater Bay Area. It is a government-funded initiative, and does not yet involve huge figures, but it is an attempt to encourage start-ups from all over the world to come to China.

Conservative China's plans make it one to watch in health care in the next five years. Its plans are centrally-government led. This is a critical initiative for the Chinese government, targeting an area of great need, and providing opportunities for western and Chinese companies alike. The market is there, the infrastructure is being put in place, and there is a move towards a more consumer-led, innovative economy. China may play the long game, but western minds can probably see there is growing confidence - and a little less nervousness - about future medtech and pharma business with China.       

By Ashley Yeo

urn:contentItem:5YBY-VYX1-JCBD-Y29K-00000-00CHANNEL 4 CHIEF ISSUES WARNING OVER BIG US TECH COMPANIES2020-03-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisHOME NEWSCHANNEL 4 CHIEF ISSUES WARNING OVER BIG US TECH COMPANIESSherna Noah, PA Senior Entertainment Correspondent

Big tech companies have set their sights on ``extending their control'' of the nation's TV sets, the chief of Channel 4 has warned.

The chief executive said US companies are ``not interested in'' content that ``serves the interest of all Britons.''

``In the very near future our concerns need to be about control of the screen itself,'' Alex Mahon said.

Speaking about Apple, Google and Amazon, she said: ``All three of these tech giants are now focused on extending their control to the most influential screen of all, the TV set.''

She said that ``one thing we can be certain of is that none of these players has any vested interest in, or even any understanding of, public-service broadcasting.

``They're certainly not interested in British-originated content that serves the interest of all Britons,'' she said,

There is no incentive for ``Silicon Valley giants'' to boost production around the UK, she said.

And she added: ``The threat could be even more severe when you look at the provision of news...

``Without a regulated Public Service Broadcasting system, our most prominent news feeds could be selected by US companies that are more concerned about profit than trust or accuracy'', she said.

``The real pain will be felt by communities whose interests are ignored when impartial and regulated journalism is buried by those who have the means to pay the most.''

She said that in the US, ``subjects such as gender or addiction or poverty'' tend to be ``seen as ways of provoking audiences, not informing them.''

But once the UK ``philosophy'' of informing viewers is gone ``it won't be coming back'', she said.

She told the Media And Telecoms 2020 & Beyond conference that there were ``serious implications for democracy and for social cohesion'' if ``we rely on operating systems that prioritise those who pay the most over those who want to reach all audiences''.

And she called for ``debate before we change our television culture into one in which the main sources of information come from people who seek only to satisfy those who can afford to buy services rather than who want to serve everyone.''

She warned that she ``wouldn't bank on us to still be doing it in the same way in 2030'' without support through legislation.

The Channel 4 chief also told the conference that there had been ``an upsurge in young audiences engaging in our news and serious factual.''

``This generation is overwhelmed by the pressure of our times, particularly the impact on them of social media. Their response to this situation has been to get more serious,'' she said.

many people will have seen and heard about, through to false reports of hospitals being overcrowded and unsafe. Reports that have at times prevented people from going to hospitals even when they have been very unwell. The committee also looked into the future harm is this problem could cause, for example they think people who might have read a lot of information that is wrong online could then refuse a Covid-19 vaccine when one is eventually offered. Given all of this, the findings of this report, the committee has been very critical of the government and have said they have raised the issue with them many times in many different context and they simply haven't acted quickly enough to tackle it.

Has the government been dragging its feet on this issue? Yes, I think it has. They said they were minded to make off, an online regulator as well, so just make them the regulator. Everybody knows this will happen, even Ofcom themselves are preparing for it so this is just a delay. We have been promised a world leading architecture for social media regulation, something that will be held up as an example in all other Western countries but we haven't got there yet and we are seeing other countries steal a march in that respect so we need to get a move on here. They have also levelled a lot of criticism at social media firms and the big tech companies themselves, saying not only have they allowed a lot of this stuff to spread but they have also at times profited from its proliferation. We have approached some of those big companies, Twitter and Facebook, to come on the programme to talk about this issue and explain what they have been doing to tackle it and instead they sent statements saying they have invested heavily in addressing misinformation online and say they have worked with government sent that every day they remove huge amounts of misinformation from their websites. Liz Bates. The US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was in London today with Chinese rather than Russian interference at the top of his agenda. He congratulated Boris Johnson on banning the Chinese firm Huawei from the UK's future 5G phone network. Mr Pompeo accused China of covering up the coronavirus outbreak, of bullying India in the Himalayas, of making illegal territorial claims at sea. And he called for a global coalition against the Communist state. Our foreign affairs correspondent Jonathan Rugman reports. If you believe the polls, then Mike Pompeo, the great survivor of the Trump administration, could soon be out of a job. But before he goes, the task of building arguably his only significant diplomatic alliance - not against Russia, the old enemy, but China instead. The Secretary of State works for a president who hopes to meet Vladimir Putin at the UN in September, so isolating Russia is not his priority. Containing China is. And what better venue to meet parliamentary backbenchers than the In and Out Club, given that the UK last week jumped out of its relationship with Huawei, having jumped in only six months earlier. What would you like the UK to do next on China? Last week the President took credit for the UK's U-turn. We convinced many countries, I did this myself for the most part, not to use Huawei. And today MPs who helped make the case against the Chinese firm got to meet Mike Pompeo before the Prime Minister did, a mark of his thanks that the UK had finally made the choice between China and the UK's most powerful ally. He wants to create an alliance of the free world to put pressure on China to change its ways, and that was refreshing. Not just America, but now talking about others like the UK, France, Germany, India and Japan. Whether you like Donald Trump or not, they are doing ethical things by trying to get American companies to disinvest in places like Xinjiang in contrast to what we were doing a few years ago, which was going there and effectively allowing ourselves to be part of China's propaganda front. The Americans are hoping that damning pictures like these of ethnic Uighur prisoners allegedly being taken to so-called education camps will persuade the British and others to impose sanctions on Chinese Communist party officials, as the US already has. But Downing Street, while busily pursuing a trade deal with the Americans, is also waiting the Trump administration out, divided from it on Iran, climate change, Israel's plan to annex the West Bank, along with Pompeo's refusal to extradite Anne Sacoolas, the American who fled justice after the death of Harry Dunn in a crash last August. They allowed her to leave last September. Dunn's mother Charlotte had pleaded for her son's death

Well, I can take the short answer to that question is yes. Politicians on both sides of the House do believe, as the chairman put it at the start of the hearing today, that the companies, the big tech giants, use their dominance, he said, to shake down small businesses and enrich themselves while closing off the market. Facebook for example is accused of using its aggressive acquisition strategy, including of companies like Instagram and WhatsApp, Amazon, by running the world's biggest online marketplace in which it is accused of favouring its own products rather than those of its competitors, Google, whose technology runs about 90% of online search, it was accused by the Chairman of stealing technology from its competitors, and Apple, that only allows users to download apps to its iPhone from its own App Store, for which it then takes a substantial cut of the sales. Well, we will hear from them, from the tech giants themselves, in a moment, but first, let's hear from our reporter Inigo Gilmore.

The big beasts of big tech, taking the oath remotely as they came under fire today from a Congress asking if they are now just too big and too powerful. The platforms have wielded their power in destructive, harmful ways in order to expand. So why does this matter? Many of the practices used by these companies have harmful economic effects. He said the industry's four leading chief executives have far too much power. And this inquiry is asking if their dominance is harming competition. Back in 1994, when America's largest tobacco companies testified before Congress... I don't believe that nicotine products are addictive... Their obstinate and scale real momentum to efforts to regulate that industry. Today, the tech giants are facing sustained criticism of a different kind, from politicians on both sides of the House. But critics can't agree on whether breaking up the companies is a practical way of constraining them. Some members of Congress want to regulate the four big tech companies and what they see as anti-competitive practices. Take Amazon - it's all about e-commerce and whether its products have an unfair advantage. For Facebook, questions about its hold on consumer data, with the tech giant ever more dominant, having acquired Instagram and WhatsApp. And for Google, accusations that its dominant search and advertising platform harms competitors, including news publishers. Finally, Apple - criticised by lawmakers over its gatekeeping control of the iPhone's App Store. The tech giant will make robust defences. -- giants. The Amazon CEO, owner of the Washington Post and the focus of numerous attacks by President Trump, was today invoking the humble beginnings of his company. From the outset today, Facebook was also in the firing line. Despite a litany of privacy scandals and record-breaking fines, Facebook continues to enjoy booming profits. $18 billion last year alone. In an election year, there is a big focus on platforms like Facebook and how information is disseminated, with President Trump accusing Facebook of censoring Conservative views. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg today, pushing back against criticism of its data gathering and dominance. Two years ago, revelations about Cambridge Analytica, including the undercover investigation by this programme, opened the way for Mark Zuckerberg to appear before Congress. Where he gave an indifferent performance, even though his inquisitors were poorly prepared. We didn't do enough to prevent these tools form being used for Hamas well. This time, there is asking the questions will presumably have done their homework. But many wonder what regulation if any will emerge from this one tech inquiry be operated remotely. Well, the tech giants obviously all deny using their dominance to stifle competition. Amazon's Jeff Bezos telling the committee that he was operating in a large and competitive market and that there was plenty of room for competitors. He said Amazon only comprised less than 4% of the US retail market. Apple's CEO Tim Cook said their goal was to achieve the best, he said, not the most, in any market, and that it doesn't have a dominant share, he said, in any product category or market in which it does business. If Apple is a gatekeeper, he said, then all we have done is make the gate wider. Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook said the tech industry was part of what he called America's success story. This

urn:contentItem:60G4-6T91-JBH6-C26S-00000-00Channel 4 News - 6:50 PM GMT2020-07-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisJon SnowU.K. NATIONALNewsChannel 4 News - 6:50 PM GMT

Includes news headlines and weather.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

is a clip from him now. I think the true nature of competition is much broader. When Google bought YouTube, they could compete against the dominant player in video, which was the cable industry. When Amazon bought Whole Foods, they could compete against Walmart.

When Facebook bought what's up, we could compete against telcos who used to charge 10 cents a text message, but not anymore. -- WhatsApp. Now people can watch a video, get groceries delivered and send private messages for free. Interesting so far throughout the hearings, most of the questioning targeted at Mark Zuckerberg and the boss of Google. Little so far at Jeff Bezos, the Amazon CEO, the world's richest man. It is the first time ever that he has been hauled in front of Congress. I think we can expect some testy exchanges between them later. Ahead of the hearing earlier, President Donald Trump couldn't resist taking a swipe at the tech companies. He said in a tweet, if Congress doesn't bring fairness to big tech, which they should have done years ago, then I will do it myself. To be fair, he has a point, we have been here before with tech companies, there is very little if any regulation of these tech giants, without whose technology it is impossible almost to use the internet. The committee promises yet another report sometime later on this summer, early fall, let's see what they have to say. Well, we did ask representatives from all four companies to speak to us, but to no avail. Matt Perault, who's a former public policy director for Facebook, testified before the same House committee last year. He's now left Facebook to work at Duke University, and joins me now from North Carolina. Matt Perault, the committee chair began by saying that our founders would not bow before a king, nor should we bow before the emperors of the online economy. From what you've seen so far, do you think these hearings will change anything? Well, I think that that is the question, you see two very different narratives in play today. The first is that these tech companies are an American success story and that they sort started off in garages and have grown to be successful, empowering businesses and people to speak more, to sell their products, to grow. On the other hand you have heard that they are a threat to America, a threat to democracy, to free speech, a threat from a surveillance perspective, and so those two narratives are in competition and you saw that on display today. Which narrative do you buy into, having once worked for Facebook but now on the outside? Well, so, I think the last time that Mark Zuckerberg testified on the Hill he was asked if Facebook was a monopoly and what he said was, it sure doesn't feel that way. That is how it felt to me when I was at Facebook. We were engaged in aggressive competition with many others in our industry and when things happened that people thought were problematic about our business like the Cambridge Analytica scandal, I did not think the company responded as if it was a monopoly, it did not feel like it was complacent, we had to respond aggressively and we were scared of advertisers and users going to use other services. Well, Amazon has been trumpeting its jobcreating credentials, Google has been talking about how it has brought technology to billions at an affordable price, is there the political will to take on these big tech companies, do you think? I think there is certainly the political will, there are a lot of representatives with political incentives right now to tactics companies, but that is not the only incentive they have and I think that has led to incoherence in US policy. You see aggressive questioning today on a variety of topics, with the Conservatives asking about issues related to bias on tech platforms, liberals asking questions about concentration of power, and on the other hand there are dynamics in American politics right now where there are very serious questions being raised about companies like TikTok and whether they, too, are a threat to American democracy and should be banned. Those two stances are incoherent. On the one hand there is the concern about the power of tech companies, but if a company like TikTok were to be banned, it would actually protect American companies. Very briefly, we broke the Cambridge Analytica story, no one from Facebook would come on, and now the boss is being quizzed by Congress, why do you think no one would be accountable to that? So, I think Facebook would disagree about whether it was held accountable, it paid a large fine to the FTC as a result of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, and I think the company has felt that it has tried to do its best to improve its privacy practices and critically the way it shares data. Matt Perault, I am sorry I have got to end it there, that is all we have got time for this evening. We are back at seven tomorrow night. Until then, that is Channel 4 News, have a lovely

are to live stream this evil massacre and is by this manager of eight to the whole world. -- spread this mantra of hate. The government's promising proposals for legislation to shut down what it says are safe spaces where people can share sick views. When Brenton Tarrant announced his impending attack, it was advertised on 8Chan, an anonymous message board, which you might not have heard of.

But in his video, before he opened fire, Tarrant pointed people to the world's biggest video site, YouTube, and its richest star, PewDiePie. I am white. Can I make that comment? But I do think that's a problem. He's had to deny allegations he's a racist. Close to 90 million people subscribe to his channel. He's said he's "absolutely sickened" Brenton Tarrant mentioned his name. At the weekend, swastikas and the message "subscribe to PewDiePie" appeared at a school in Oxford. They were Brenton Tarrant's exact words. Police are investigating. Google, which owns YouTube, says it's removed tens of thousands of videos and terminated hundreds of accounts, but there is much more work to do. This expert on political violence says mainsteam media, not just the internet, is guilty of giving far right nationalists space, compared to other extremists. I don't think that this is something that is produced through social media space at all. This is leaking over from the mainstream. This is mainstream political discourse at this point. Islamophobic rhetoric, anti-immigrant sentiments, anti-women sentiments, these are not something that you are finding in the dark corners of the Internet, these are being normalised in the a bigger split campaigns in recent years. -- biggest political campaigns. In Stanwell in Surrey, a man's been arrested after a stabbing amd police have declared a terrorist incident. He was shouting out, "All Muslims should be dead. I'll kill a Muslim. White supremacy rules. There have been references to the New Zealand attack online and on the streets. We can probably expect more. Joining me now is the Labour MP Jo Stevens, who's a member of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport parliamentary committee. The live streaming for 70 minutes, the uploading countless times of this horrific footage has shocked people. -- 17 minutes. How urgently do you think governments throughout the world should respond? This has been urgent for some time. The atrocities over the last few days have just shown a real light on this in a way it has not done before. We have been calling on Parliament here, on our digital, culture, media and sport select committee, for action from the government and there's been calls for action all around the world, and I'm afraid the age of self-regulation for big tech companies and social media companies has gone. They have had their chance and they have blown it. I have heard similar sentiments around the world, the US, the EU, the UK, I mean, the UK digital minister today said 15 voluntary codes of practice have been agreed with online platforms since 2008. Why do you think it has taken so long for governments to arguably protect citizens better? I think the approach has been, it is almost like whack a mole, the social media companies will never do anything proactively, so they will only ever take action and then they don't take very much action when something happens and they are full steam to a position to do it. We have been waiting for the government to publish its online harms white paper for some time. Our committee published its interim report last summer and we had a very poor response to our recommendations from government. We published another report just a few weeks ago, and now we need, you know, we really need some urgent action. These companies are quite happy to take the plaudits and the profits but they are never happy to accept the consequences of what their sprawling services are enabling. Facebook and YouTube would say they are doing quite a lot, removing quite a lot of videos. Is it unfair to blame online platforms for the filth that people want to put on them? Well, they argue they are not publishers, they refused to be regulated in the way that other publishers, like broadcast media or print media, are, because they say they are not responsible for the content which is uploaded onto their platforms. But they do perform editing functions, so they do take stuff down, not quickly enough, so this argument they are not publishers, I don't think, holds. We now need to force them into a position where the recommendations that we have made include a statutory power for an independent regulator, with a code of ethics, with sanctions, legal powers, if they are breached, and to make sure that where they do not follow those rules, that they suffer a heavy financial sanction, because I'm
