Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WXK-HG41-DXH2-61X1-00000-00ChannelAdvisor Corp Corporate Call - Final2019-08-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexis082219a12706914.714ChannelAdvisor Corp Corporate Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* David J. Spitz

ChannelAdvisor Corporation - CEO & Director

* Tamara Gibbs

ChannelAdvisor Corporation - Marketing Communication Manager

Presentation

TAMARA GIBBS, MARKETING COMMUNICATION MANAGER, CHANNELADVISOR CORPORATION: Good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining today's Webinar, Connect Live with ChannelAdvisor's CEO. My name is Tamara Gibbs, Marketing Communications Manager at ChannelAdvisor, and I'll be your moderator for today.

First off, we have a few housekeeping items we want to run through. (Operator Instructions) David will first present some slides, then we'll transition to a live Q&A. (Operator Instructions) And yes, a recording of the webinar will be available within the next few days. We'll send out a link to the recording and a copy of the presentation, so please keep an eye out for that. So that covers our housekeeping items.

Now for the reason we are all here. Today's webinar features David Spitz, CEO of ChannelAdvisor. David is responsible for leading the company in its mission to provide brands and retailers with the software and services needed to connect to the empowered consumer through marketing, selling and fulfillment capabilities. ChannelAdvisor has over 2,700 customers globally, connects to over 140 marketplaces and generated over $10 billion in GMV in 2018. David is here to share his industry insight and thoughts on the state of e-commerce today and beyond as well as answer your questions live.

David, we are so excited to hear from you, happy that you're here joining us today. First, we want to help the audience get to know you a little bit better. We know everything about you in terms of a CEO, running a great company. But folks may not know that you're a father of 6 children, ranging in age from college all the way to middle school.

DAVID J. SPITZ, CEO & DIRECTOR, CHANNELADVISOR CORPORATION: Tamara, that's correct. So we are busy both on the work front and on the home front. You know, and in fact, this week, we're sending 3 of them off to college at various years. So it's also a busy week in terms of getting all the logistics work out.

So hi, everyone. Thanks for joining the call today. We're super excited to try out this live Q&A format. We'll see how it goes, and hopefully give you some insights and some thoughts as you think about what's next for your businesses. So as Tamara said, I'm David Spitz, I'm CEO here at ChannelAdvisor. I've been here for 13 years. And in any kind of Internet space, including e-commerce, 13 years is a long time. You get to see a lot of different things and a lot of changes. You know the things like smartphones weren't around when I started at ChannelAdvisor, which is kind of hard to imagine. So it's just been a whole lot of change. And I think over those many years, it's been possible to kind of see what are the trends that have happened, and what are the trends that are coming, and we'll talk about that in a little bit. But -- so definitely have some perspective on the industry. And I definitely want to respect everybody's time. I know people are busy, and so I want to get to Q&A as quickly as possible. So let's go ahead and jump right in.

So for those of you who have attended our annual customer show, and I know many of you have, you know that I -- one of the things I'd like to kind of anchor on is this notion of what are the key forces that are shaping the landscape? Sometimes I call these the tectonic forces. And they're basically the things that are happening around us that most of us don't have control over, but they're really important and they have the potential to really impact everybody's business, both for good and for bad. And so having an awareness of these trends, I think, is really (technical difficulty) China. And China has been in the news a lot lately as it relates to some of the geopolitical and trade tensions that are going on. But it's worth remembering that China has been now, for a number of years, the largest e-commerce market in the world. It's growing really, really quickly. There's a lot of interesting things, I think, we can learn in the West from things -- how things have developed in China, like mobile payments, chat apps that end up becoming whole ecosystems themselves and of course, currently, there is some turbulence going on in terms of cross-border trade and some of the tariffs and all of that. But China is a force to be reckoned with, depending on who you read, anywhere from maybe 30% to 40% of China -- of sales, for example, on Amazon in western countries, in Europe and in the U.S. actually come from Chinese sellers. So you can't -- even if you're just a seller, for example, in the U.S. or in Europe, you can't ignore China. It's an important facet of e-commerce.

Next, of course, is Amazon. I'm sure you've all heard of Amazon, continues to gain share and really drive a lot of innovation in the space, whether it's around logistics and getting products now in 1 day to most of the population. Amazon continues to set the bar as far as what consumers expect when it comes to e-commerce. And I've spent quite a lot of years, not only working pretty closely with Amazon as a strategic partner, but also just kind of observing how they operate. And I think that most of the time, they're really not that complicated of a company when you think about the things that are important to them. And it's not always that hard to predict what we think Amazon might do next. So that's potentially an interesting area for Q&A.

Next is logistics. One of the things that's really driven the growth of e-commerce is the increasing speed at which consumers can get their packages. When I started at ChannelAdvisor, the average delivery time for a package was probably 5 or 6 days, right? So it wasn't the kind of thing where you'd go and purchase something you needed tomorrow or the -- or a couple of days from now. It's really the expectation now is for most consumers is that they're going to order something, and for sure, within a couple of days, if not 1 day or even same day, they're going to get those orders. And so that's created a real battlefield in the space of logistics that, if you look at some of the stories around like FedEx kind of ending its partnership with Amazon and some of the things that other companies are doing, you can tell that this is a real battle ground. And we predicted this a few years ago. And I would say, I've even been surprised that how quickly it's become kind of a primary battlefield in e-commerce.

Next is brands. So this was another hypothesis we developed a number of years ago, where we felt that digital would continue to not only disrupt overall retail, but compress the distance between brands and consumers. So if you think about the metaphor I use is e-commerce is causing a shift from Blockbuster to Netflix, if I use the metaphor of how people consume movies and I apply that to retail, it's the same thing, right? The path to the consumer is different. And if you're a brand, you may still generate 80% or 90% of your revenues from your traditional retail partners, but probably the growth area is e-commerce. And so how do you think about channel conflict? How do you think about direct-to-consumer? How do you think about things like fulfillment, things that maybe you haven't had in your wheelhouse previously? But we continue to believe that brands will get closer to the consumer as digital and e-commerce continues to grow.

Then we have mobile. It seems almost quite now to talk about it. We've been talking about this for a number of years. Although it still surprises me how frequently I speak to customers, and they don't think mobile first. So for most of our customers now, the majority of traffic is from a mobile device. And for many customers, the majority of transactions are actually from a mobile device. So if you're not spending your day primarily thinking about the mobile experience for your customers and you come to work every day and you're working on a desktop and kind of starting with that, that's probably a backwards way of thinking. So just remember that the consumer now is mobile-first. And in a number of countries, that's the only way that they interact with the Internet.

So -- and then lastly, is data, right? So we've long believed that data and the strategic use of data is really the thing that drives success in e-commerce, right? So if you are kind of running your business blind or shooting from the hip or guessing on pricing or guessing on inventory levels, we think, eventually, you end up losing out to folks that are really adroit in using data and using data and machine learning and things like that to really make intelligent decisions. That's why we've invested in things like our Algorithmic Repricer and our machine learning-based demand forecaster. We just think that data is a real asset. And for a lot of companies data is kind of -- they have mountains of it, but they don't know what to do with it, and so we spend a lot of time thinking about and deploying solutions to take that data and make it actionable for you in the day-to-day.

And then one of the forces that I added this year that is new for the industry is regulatory pressure. So there's been a lot of news headlines this year about Facebook testifying in front of Congress or antitrust issues being raised, both in Europe and in the U.S. against, what I would call, just sort of big tech, right? So folks like Amazon and Google and Facebook and others. And so there's this kind of rapidly rising temperature, I guess, I would say, where it used to be that if you're a big tech, you are seen as innovators and driving society forward. And I think in many cases, that's still very much the case. But in the last couple of years, I think it's also become more and more difficult for big tech to be -- to kind of stay out of those crosshairs. And we talked about this at our conference, and as I look at history, if I look at IBM in the 1960s and '70s and Microsoft in the 1990s, and we try to draw lessons from what happens when companies get in the crosshairs from a regulatory and antitrust perspective, the thing we typically see is it's really, really distracting for the company or the companies that are getting targeted. And so very often that creates -- and it's a long process, it takes years for that kind of stuff to work through, and we see that the companies that are targeted get distracted and sometimes that creates opportunities for new entrants to come in. So this is going to be like a multiyear thing to see play out, and it's really hard to predict exactly what's going to happen. But it could lead to a period of a little bit of instability in the market as some of the bigger companies have to contend with some of these pressures and maybe it'll create opportunities for smaller entrants to come in.

So when you think about all of this complexity, I think a key thing is to remember that at ChannelAdvisor, our mission is to connect and optimize the word commerce. And at our core, we really got connecting and making it easier for you to manage all of this complexity, right? So whether you're struggling with the myriad ways to do digital marketing or selling and listing and optimizing performance across multiple channels or how to do fulfillment and logistics in a way that satisfies your consumers, but keep your costs under control, all of that is what we think about every day here at ChannelAdvisor to make it easy to connect to hundreds of channels and systems and endpoints. And we think every day about new ways to help you more successful and more competitive. So whether you're an entrepreneur with a new brand that's ready to take over the world or the largest CPG or consumer electronics company in the world, we have the scale at ChannelAdvisor and the breadth to be your strategic e-commerce partner.

So enough about us, I think it's time to jump into Q&A. And what I'll do is maybe ask Tamara to say a couple of words about if you have a question, how we would like you to submit that question so that we can answer it.

Questions and Answers

TAMARA GIBBS: Yes, David, we're so excited for this part of it, right, how fun is this? (Operator Instructions) David, just listening to you talk about all this evolution that's occurring so rapidly, brands becoming retailers, vice versa, logistics becomes a major issue, there's talk of regulation. If you can look into the future, your crystal ball, 10 years out from now in terms of e-commerce, what do you see?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. I think e-commerce, like we said earlier, is a rapidly evolving space, but it kind of comes in ways, right? So there's periods where, maybe for a few years, not a whole lot changes. And then there's periods where maybe a new entrant comes in or something changes, like, for example, Amazon introducing Prime in 2005, and it kind of shakes up the world. And so as a consequence, that's why those trends are really so important, right? We have to -- I know that everybody is running their business, and every day they're looking at dashboards and KPIs and trying to figure out why were sales up yesterday or down yesterday, and how much -- and so it's super, super easy to get caught up in that day-to-day of just running a business or running an e-commerce operation. But if you're not paying attention to some of those longer-term trends, they have a tendency to kind of sneak up on you, and then one day, boom, they hit you, and you're not necessarily prepared for it.

So when I think out 10 years, gosh, that's like -- in any other industry, that would be like trying to forecast 100 years out, right? So it's pretty hard. And I don't even know if 10 years out, you can even do it. But I think a few assumptions are probably say, like, number one, I think there is going to be more e-commerce. So I think share of wallet continues to shift towards e-commerce. It's just more convenient, right? And as fulfillment and logistics gets faster and more instantaneous and more products, like earlier this year, I was talking about the rise of online mattress companies, right? Like who'd have guessed 5 years ago that, that was a thing, right? That people are actually willing to buy something that you would have thought would be like the pinnacle of something you'd want to touch and see and try out in a showroom. But then you have these business model innovations, like Casper, saying, "Hey, you can get the mattress and use it for a 100 days, and if you don't like it, return it." So it's not just technical innovation, it's business model innovation. And that's why it's so important to keep an eye on these trends, right? Because if you're a traditional mattress company and you kind of had this assumption that the world couldn't necessarily change or you just didn't believe it was possible, some well-funded entrepreneur somewhere that's got a lot of venture capital sloshing around all of a sudden can eat your lunch.

So I think probably China continues to grow. I think e-commerce continues to gain share of wallet. I think fulfillment and delivery speeds continue to rapidly increase, right? So we've gone -- Prime has gone from 2 days to 1 day. We live in the middle of nowhere, my family and I, and we have Prime now. And so to my kids, it's like second nature that they can order something and get it within an hour. To me, it still blows my mind, right? So I thought for a long time that at some point, Amazon gets smart enough about your purchase patterns that they might start delivering stuff to your house before you actually order it because they know you're probably going to need it, maybe they know you're likely to be out of paper towel or toilet paper or whatever. And if they're starting to do all those last-mile logistics, and they're driving around in vans anyway and are passing by your house and maybe picking up a return, well, why not leave that product that they think you're going to order, and maybe they just pick it up a little bit later if it's not a product that you want. So I think we'll continue to see a lot of innovation there.

TAMARA GIBBS: Right. Yes. So we do have our first question from Shane Doyle, a question regarding customer acquisition for D2C brands so as in primarily via social platforms, like Instagram. David, at what point could a growing D2C brand leverage ChannelAdvisor to expand their reach?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. That's a great question, Shane. Thank you for that. So I think a couple of things. Number one, we think social is important, and it's an area that we continue to invest in. For example, we've partnered with Instagram, on Instagram Checkout, and there's a lot of interesting stuff there that -- I think for a number of years, social was kind of, what I would call, experimental when it comes to e-commerce. I mean, obviously, it's great more kind of top-of-funnel if you're trying to build brand awareness and trying to build a story and get consumer attention, but it was more top-of-funnel. But I think all of these channels, right, whether you're talking about traditional ones like Facebook and Instagram, and of course, folks like Pinterest, more and more, I think, what they're realizing is, there's no reason why they can't kind of move down that funnel and close the loop a little bit more, right? Because it's not a great consumer experience if you just see, like, if you follow somebody on Instagram, let's say, and you really want the products, and you have to go somewhere else to purchase it, and it's not closing the loop. And of course, if you're Instagram, like, why wouldn't you want to close the loop and make it super easy for your customers to act on those kinds of things.

So the first thing I would say is that ChannelAdvisor is focused pretty intently on what this means and what's the best way to bring it to our customers. But then beyond that, I think you have to acknowledge and be realistic about where consumers shop, right? So close to half of U.S. e-commerce is on Amazon. So -- and I know not everybody wants to sell on Amazon because you have to think about do you own the consumer? Does -- is there a risk that Amazon might see your success and try to replicate the product or maybe other sellers will try to replicate the product? So there's pros and cons to it. But at the end of the day, half the population prefers to shop on Amazon as their primary way, then you really have to think about it, right? And then once you think about Amazon, there are so many other channels that you can start to go through, right? So it could be like an Etsy, Google Shopping Actions really taken off for us, and I think it's kind of a sort of the sleeper hit that people may not be ready for if they're not using it this Q4. We launched this year Target+, which is their online marketplace. Of course, you've got sites like eBay and Walmart, but we support over 140 marketplaces today. And one of the things we try to do is make it super easy that once you're on the platform, so just basically go out to as many as are relevant to you by geography or by product category.

So I think what you have sort of -- if you're a direct-to-consumer brand and you've got sort of the basics in place in terms of fulfillment and customer service, and you've got kind of the e-commerce wheels starting to turn a little bit, then it's about scale, right? And as long as you're prepared for that scale plugging into these channels and really becoming -- having e-commerce become a mainstream part of your go-to-market strategy, I think, is really important.

TAMARA GIBBS: Yes. Another question here, David, from a major player, eBay. eBay launched a managed fulfillment program. So how will that work for eBay sellers?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. So I think eBay fulfillment is a great step in the right direction. I mean, obviously, Amazon has, gosh, almost a 20-year head start in the industry, not specifically with eBay, but in the industry of seeing logistics and fulfillment as a key differentiator because I think it's clear to everyone that, at the end of the day, if you get your products faster as a consumer, that's great, right? So -- and I think the rest of the industry has been a little bit slow to react to that because let's face it, building hundreds of fulfillment centers and starting to think about logistics is a capital-intensive, multi-billion dollar, frankly, multi-decade thing, right? And so I think it's not surprising that Amazon kind of has this mindset that thinks on those time frames and so they're willing to deploy billions of dollars and build lots of facilities and et cetera, et cetera, to deliver on that consumer promise. And so I'm really happy to see eBay do this. I think that one of my views is the vast majority of people in e-commerce actually do their own fulfillment. And you have to be thinking to yourself, can you really afford to keep up with that changing consumer expectation, right? So maybe you're a midsized brand or a midsized retailer, and you have 2 or 3 fulfillment centers and yes, you can ship to the whole country in a matter of a few days, but like how are you really going to keep up with 2-day, 1-day, same-day shipping? And I think very, very few people can actually afford the capital requirements to build out that capability. So I've always viewed partnering in logistics and fulfillment as being really, really key. And I think it's great that the channels are starting to offer this kind of capability. Shopify launched their fulfillment network, eBay is launching theirs. And in most of these alternatives to fulfillment by Amazon what you're seeing is kind of more of an asset-light model, where some combination of maybe your warehouses or third-party logistics providers or other fulfillment providers are kind of getting assembled and organized under a software layer that basically says, "Hey, this is where you need to ship your products, and this is how the products are going to get shipped out when they're ordered." So I think, fundamentally, it's great that eBay is doing it. Obviously, execution is key, and when it comes to fulfillment, you have to have kind of like a five nines' reliability, right, to make sure the right product is getting to the right person at the right time. And I think the next challenge for everybody that's competing with Amazon at some level is what is Amazon doing around logistics and last-mile delivery, right? So some of their Flex drivers and the things that they're doing in ultimately owning last-mile delivery is going to create, I think, yet another competitive advantage. But I think it's great that eBay is doing it. I think it's a step in the right direction.

And I frankly think that almost every major channel or every major e-commerce player out there is going to have to have some kind of answer to fulfillment. We created ChannelAdvisor fulfillment network, the launch of, well, I guess, about 1 year, 1.5 years ago after the acquisition of a company called HubLogix, and that's been phenomenally successful. I mean, our customers love that they can come to ChannelAdvisor and say, "Hey, I've got 2 owned and operated warehouses, but I don't have great coverage of the West Coast, and I'd like to partner with a 3PL, and therefore, I'd like to be able to route orders based on -- in real time, see cost, et cetera, et cetera." So I'm a big proponent of partnering in this space and encourage people to think about that.

TAMARA GIBBS: So let's talk about the biggest challenge for retailers. What do you think they're dealing with right now?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. So like I said earlier, digital causes compression of time and space, right? So what I mean by that is, let's just go back, like, 50 years ago, right? So 50 years ago, you didn't have a choice. I mean, yes, you could get on the phone and maybe you had a Sears catalog and you could order something from somewhere distant, and eventually it would be delivered to you. But realistically, almost all of your commerce was local, right? You had to walk or drive to the store. You purchase something, it was probably a mom-and-pop kind of operated thing. And when you think about what digital does, digital gives you the ability to search and seek and find and purchase products from anywhere in the world, like as easily, and frankly, in some cases, more easily than walking down the street and going to a store. So when I say it compresses time and distance, that's what I mean.

And so it's not hard to imagine that if you're a 1950's mom and pop, like, how do you compete with that, right? You probably don't have the wherewithal to address the global audience or to source product from a global supply chain. And so digital also tends to drive kind of winner-take-most outcomes, right? So that's why I think we're seeing more and more transaction volume and power get concentrated in companies like Amazon or companies like Walmart, who have the scale and the breadth to get there. So I think the general trend is, if you're a retailer and shopping online becomes more and more convenient, obviously, that's an important growth area for you as a retailer, but at the end of the day, what is your differentiated value proposition for the consumer? If you want them to come into a physical store, why would they, right? They've got to fight traffic, they've got to park, they've got to kind of -- do you provide them an experience that actually draws them in, right? I think some companies do that well. Others, I think, don't do it so well, right? And even online, if you're a retailer, what's the reason that somebody's going to come to you versus going to someone else? We've been working, for example, with REI for many, many years, and I'm sure most of you know REI, a great retailer/brand of incredible products geared towards the outdoor enthusiasts, and they do a lot in their stores with employees who are super knowledgeable about products, right? So if you're going rock climbing or camping or whatever, if you want to ask about a particular, like, -- in a lot of retail experience, as you -- first of all, you have to go find somebody to help you and good luck with that, and second of all, when you find them, they have no idea what the products do, right? So REI does a great job of giving that great in-store experience.

And then online, same kind of thing, right? It's more about the experience and the story and how these things work together, and they dovetail it nicely with their stores. And so I think retailers really have to think that way, right? How to make e-commerce, not only a central part of their story, but how to make their whole retail operations something that gives consumers a reason to want to come in or want to work with them.

TAMARA GIBBS: Great insight, David. We have a question from a ChannelAdvisor customer. How do you see marketplaces competing with Amazon to gain market share?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. Great question. I think that -- let's start -- let's step back with what has created success for Amazon? So the first thing I would say is, you have to go back to first principles. Amazon has long believed that the key things that consumers are looking for are 3 things: value, selection and convenience, right? In other words, if -- and this goes back 20 years, right? When they talk about being Earth's biggest store, right? So they knew -- Amazon knew that if they were a place that a consumer can come and find almost any product for sale on Earth and the products were going to be priced well and not only were they priced well, but there's a convenience factor where you knew you can order that product and it wouldn't take 3 weeks to get to you, but it might get there in 2 days or whatever. But that would be a pretty compelling thing. So they would attract more sellers to the platform, which would attract more consumers to the platform and you get this kind of virtuous famous napkin diagram that Jeff Bezos drew, right?

And so from my perspective, you have to remember those things. And I think investments in marketplace and fulfillment, especially I've heard from ex executives at Amazon that they view their key competitive advantages actually being a logistics company, right? So like anybody can build a website, right? Like those -- there's not the barrier to entry necessarily that's high in that area, but boy, having a couple of hundred of fulfillment centers and delivery vans and all of that, like that starts to become a pretty high hurdle for a competitor. And that goes back to the question earlier about eBay, eBay's fulfillment network and others that are doing similar things in the space, I'm really glad to see people moving. Amazon has a heck of a head start, but I'm really glad to see people moving in the direction of trying to address this notion of, I don't necessarily have to shop on Amazon to get fast delivery. Like, that's the key thing that I think people are addressing. So the other thing I think that is a good competitive angle is being really good in a particular vertical. So look at Etsy, right? So Etsy is known for handcrafted types of goods and can build an experience around that, right? Where as a shopper, you're connecting with sort of the artisanal seller and really building up an experience there. We work, for example, with automotive marketplace or marketplace of automotive part marketplaces. If you think about buying car parts, there's a lot of information you didn't know about like does this brakepad fit my make model year? And how do I install it? Is there a video? Is there a community to help me when I get stuck on a project? Well, it's very hard for someone like Amazon to have a really deep, great experience that goes super deep in a category like that. Whereas if you're in auto parts, automotive marketplace, like that's all you do, right? And you can really build community around that.

So I think that, that's a key area for some of the emerging marketplaces we see is that they're really focused on a particular category or niche, and they go deep on content and experience that's specific to that category or niche. I think it's going to be pretty hard to try to attack Amazon head-on though, and try to be the general merchandise provider that like has -- what advantage are you ultimately going to have. I think Walmart has a chance because Walmart has a differentiated asset of something like 5,000 stores, right, that they can leverage for not only things like logistics and delivery, but just tying together that experience. But for most retailers, I'm not sure that that's realistic.

TAMARA GIBBS: And here's a great question we just got in, David, that kind of segues into your comments about building community via marketplaces. (Operator Instructions) But again, David, this question from Akron Fell asking what is the future of e-commerce? Is it own marketplaces or e-commerce?

DAVID J. SPITZ: So -- oh, I think, okay. So if I understand the question, it's really kind of like should I focus on my own storefront predominantly or should I sell just through marketplaces? That's a great question. And I think my answer is, I don't know that it's a binary question. I think you should do -- it depends on the product. So I don't know what product category you sell or if you're a brand or a reseller. But in general, what I would say is, you should leverage both. Obviously, the benefits of having your store platform is you own the customer relationship, you have 100% control over how you merchandise and a story that you tell. So there's a lot of benefits to having your owned and operated website. But then the trick there is, how are you going to attract people to it, right? So there are millions of websites out there that sell some sort of product, and you have to rise above the noise, right? So advertising on Google is not cheap, right? And again, this depends, like if you have a proprietary product with a well-known brand, like, let's say, you're YETI, right? So it's easier if you're YETI because everybody knows the name, and they go to Google and they type YETI, and YETI probably has to spend a lot on the money on the brand terms, but at the end of the day, they're going to get, obviously, some amount of traffic, both organic and inorganic to that site. If you haven't yet established your brand, then that's harder, right? You might just be getting a trickle of traffic, you might not be really driving a whole lot and that's where marketplaces come in, right? Because if more than 50%, if we take Amazon and we take eBay and we take some of the emerging marketplaces like Walmart and Target and Google Shopping Actions, that's really the majority of e-commerce, right?

And the other point I want to make that I think is important when it relates to marketplaces, if you look in the East, if you look at China, Southeast Asia, India, some of the countries where people kind of skip the entire desktop realm and went straight to mobile, on a mobile device, a website is not the ideal thing, right? Because people are not going to download 50 different retailer or brand apps in their phone, they're probably going to download like a Flipkart or an Amazon or a Tmall, Alibaba, whatever is appropriate in their country. They're going to have a couple of apps on their phone, and we think that mobile devices, think about that 10 square inch real estate that is your phone screen. That's the most precious real estate that there is in retail. And increasingly, we -- when I said earlier, that digital creates from winner-take-all models, that's kind of what I mean. I think that if we fast forward 5 or 10 years, almost all consumers will go through a small number of apps to get to product purchases, right? So we think marketplaces continue to take share of wallet. And so I think if you decide not to sell on marketplaces, you end up on this kind of shrinking island of demand.

But I would do both, right, because you're going to get some traffic to your web store, you're going to have that consumer relationship, you're going to have an opportunity to control a little bit more and get more direct feedback. But I don't see it as a binary strategy. I think you can do both, in general.

TAMARA GIBBS: Yes. Great advice, David. We've seen a number of DNVBs pop up in our space, any advice on how to compete against them?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. So for those of you don't know, DNVB is digitally native vertical brands. So think of some of the more popular examples like Allbirds, Warby Parker, some of these companies that had a great product idea, and were sort of born online, and in many cases were online-only for a long time. Now what's interesting is a lot of them have actually started to go retail, right? So some of these have opened stores or started selling through other stores. So it's a hot topic. But I think it's a little bit -- it's easy to get a little bit drawn in by all the press that they get. If you actually look at the data, it's actually pretty tough sledding for a lot of digitally native vertical brands or DNVBs. There's a guy named Web Smith, who runs a news letter in a site called 2PM, and it's at 2pml.com. If you don't subscribe to his newsletter, you should. He has had a really good rift going over the last probably, I don't know, 4 or 6 months where he's really done a deep dive into the space of digitally native vertical brands, and what he finds is that the hit rate is actually pretty low, right? So for every Allbirds that you hear about, there's 50 that probably had a good idea and really didn't gain traction or get the kind of following that they wanted. But even the successful ones, right? I mean, go and read the news articles about, like, honesty over the last couple of years, right? Even the more successful ones don't actually scale up to huge amounts of revenue. So Harry's was -- a lot of these brands get acquired by the more traditional, like CPG, companies, who say, "Wow, here's an up encumber, and we really need to have this digital DNA, let's go acquire them." And by most accounts, even the most successful ones have $50 million, $100 million, $150 million in revenue. I mean that's great, and that's for sure a success, but that -- compare that to the revenue of a Unilever or P&G or other brands.

So I think some of the DNVB stuff gets a little played up a little bit. But it is an interesting trend. But I think it's also really interesting that the most successful ones, you end up seeing having a retail strategy, right? So like that we talked earlier about the mattress companies. I'm pretty sure it was Casper that had a deal with Target, right? So some of their mattresses are now being sold in Target stores, and I assume online on target.com as well. So it kind of indicates that maybe the reach to consumers shouldn't be purely digital for most players. Like if you really want to reach all the -- maximize your reach to consumers, being purely digital may not actually be the right answer.

TAMARA GIBBS: Yes. A dynamic approach to it as well. We want to remind folks that we have time for 1 last question. We do have this question coming in. As a small brand, what are the top things you think we should focus on to help grow our business?

DAVID J. SPITZ: Yes. Well, I could speak for probably an hour on that topic. I guess what I would say, first and foremost, you got to have first principles, right? So what does your brand stand for, and how do you focus on an incredible consumer experience throughout the process? And I don't just mean the product, right? I mean the ordering process, the delivery process, like we actually ordered ourselves a Casper mattress for a guestroom, probably a couple of months ago, I guess. And of course, I've read about this process where it comes in a box and you open the box and it inflates itself. And even though I knew that, I was pretty impressed when we got it, right? So we get this thing, it's delivered when it's expected to be -- it's not like buying from a traditional mattress company where they give you like an 8-hour window, where you have to stay home and then they miss the window anyway and they're late and they break something while they're carrying the matters. I mean this box, my wife and I could lift it. We brought it in, we brought it up to the guestroom and my wife was like totally shocked, like we literally opened it, and it didn't take like a day to inflate, like that thing like took on its original shape in minutes, right? So it was pretty cool.

And so it's not just the purchasing and the delivery experience, but also the unboxing experience and then things like the return experience, right? We talked earlier about business model innovation, where just to stay on the Casper theme, right, if you're not happy with that mattress, you have 100 days to decide if it's the thing that you want, and if you don't like it somebody will come, package it up and take it away, which I think is great. So you have to think about the customer experience. But I think a lot of people, they think that just means product. And product is one element of customer experience, right? So you have to think about that fully closed loop. And then I think once you've got that dialed in, then I think it's really important to get your products to show up everywhere where consumers are shopping for that product, like make it easier for them to find it. I think that's really, really important.

And the last thing I'd add is that I'm entrepreneur myself, right? I started several companies, and I know what it's like to start with nothing. And you have to be willing to quickly adapt to feedback. So when I look at most of the success stories out there, it's easy to look at the success stories once they're successful. But if you really go back and you look at their history, there's almost always at least a couple of existential crises that come along where they didn't know if they were going to make it, and they had a pivot or adapt or take feedback or make something really different about their business. And that's not always the thing that gets the press. What gets the press is like the phenomenal success, but if you really dig in and you see what they had to go through to get there, so I think as -- if you're a small brand, whether you're an entrepreneur or maybe you're entrepreneur within a larger company and your job is to launch a small brand, you -- boy, you have to be really adaptive, right? You have to be willing to listen and make changes and do it really quickly, right? You can't -- you don't have the luxury of doing months-long consumer studies because if you go out there and you screw something up and your review is tanked, like it's pretty hard to recover, right? So the minute you get some kind of indication or feedback that something needs to change, you have to be willing to jump on that really quickly.

TAMARA GIBBS: Wow, David, this has been wonderful hearing from you getting your insights on the industry, and we're certainly very appreciative of everyone who submitted questions. We want to be mindful of everyone's time. If we didn't get to your question, don't worry about it. We're going to follow up with you after the webinar. And David, thank you, again. We know you have a busy schedule, and we appreciate you taking the time to chat with us. And everyone who registered for the webinar, you will receive the slides and recording, so be sure to look out for that in your e-mail. For the rest of us, on behalf of ChannelAdvisor, thank you for registering, thank you for joining us, and have a wonderful day.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XXM-5591-DXH2-600W-00000-00Chaos in Iran; Investors Shrug Off Iran Tensions; Combatting Homelessness Crisis; Ghosn News Conference Tomorrow 8:00 a.m. ET; Michelle Obama's New Gig; Ghosn Speaks Out; Fantasy Fraud; We Have A Wiener!2020-01-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTKenneth Rogoff, Rob Smith, Chris Hyzy, John Paul DeJoriaNEWSFinancial010703cb.231Chaos in Iran; Investors Shrug Off Iran Tensions; Combatting Homelessness Crisis; Ghosn News Conference Tomorrow 8:00 a.m. ET; Michelle Obama's New Gig; Ghosn Speaks Out; Fantasy Fraud; We Have A Wiener!Maria Bartiromo, Gerri Willis, Jon Hilsenrath, Dagen McDowell, Stuart Varney, Rick Leventhal, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back.

Our top story this hour -- chaos in Iran. At least 40 people trampled to death in a stampede yesterday during the Iranian General Qasem Soleimani's funeral.

Rick Leventhal is live in Jerusalem this morning with more -- Rick.

RICK LEVENTHAL, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT: And Maria -- it's not clear what sparked this stampede but we know that the crowds have been massive in Iran, both yesterday for the funeral procession, and today for the actual burial. And at some point this stampede did break out.

And Iranian TV is now reporting at least 40 dead and well over 200 people injured, trampled by this crowd that gathered for the funeral of that Iranian general who was taken out in the drone strike in Iraq late last week.

The crowd again in the millions yesterday and today, and a grieving accompanied by angry rhetoric. Threats to set U.S. facilities on fire, chants of "death to Israel" in the crowd. And a vote by Iran's parliament to officially designate the U.S. military, a terrorist force for taking out the leader of Iran's Revolutionary Guard, a man blamed by the U.S. killing and maiming hundreds of U.S. troops and thousands others.

Of course, President Trump has promised a swift and overwhelming response if Iran tries to retaliate and he has got the tools to do it including the F-35 A2 Lightning Fighter jet. 52 of them rocketing into the sky one after another, a so-called elephant walk takeoff from the Hill Air Force Base in Utah, fully armed and ready for battle.

A squadron of F-35s from Utah is now deployed here in the region. And Fox News has confirmed that the Air Force is also sending six B-52 bombers to Diego Garcia, an island base in the Indian Ocean. So they're definitely gearing up for the possibility of having to strike back if Iran tries to make retaliatory strikes against U.S. interests.

And by the way, Maria -- there is now a warning from the U.S. to ships in the Middle East to watch out for possibly retaliatory attacks in the waterways and straits around this region. So ships on alert -- anyone with any connection to the U.S. is being warned to look out.

BARTIROMO: All right. Rick -- we'll be watching. This is a dangerous situation. Rick Leventhal joining us there --

LEVENTHAL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- with the very latest. Thank you -- Rick.

Meanwhile, markets scaling back a sell-off after the airstrike last week. Futures right now showing a gain at the start of trading this morning. Investors largely shrugging off this conflict.

Yesterday markets turned around completely and then some, finishing in the green, up 68 points on the Dow Industrials when all is said and done. Gold, as you can see, it was a complete reversal by the close yesterday. Nasdaq was up 50 points but still in record territory.

Gold, meanwhile, is -- has been rising. It is certainly looking like a safe haven. The precious metal jumping to nearly $1,600 an ounce, the highest level since 2013. Gold is up about 7 percent just in the last month.

Bank of America Private Bank and Merrill chief investment officer, Chris Hyzy is with us to weigh on this. And Chris -- it's great to see you this morning.

CHRIS HYZY, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, BANK OF AMERICA PRIVATE BANK: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Why do you think markets are shrugging this off?

HYZY: I think it's partly the just sheer momentum that we saw in December. You can look at flows, you look at a number of different things, not just the performance of global equity markets, spreads, or what have you. I think there's a lot of liquidity out there, number one. Central banks plus the fact that dollars in investment accounts are rising. So cash allocations are going up, largely speaking because the dividends and interests and other things.

But also there's money in the system. Personal income is going up as a percentage of -- within the household. So it's not a perfect positive storm as it relates to the economy but it certainly has based out. And the next 12 months it should be the positive improvement factor.

So let me get those big momentum in risk assets even though it's a very dangerous situation, a very important and serious situation that until there is a retaliation that is economically harmful, investors will tend to shrug it off.

BARTIROMO: Until we actually see something that shakes the very strong backdrop that we've had -- solid consumer, 50-year low in unemployment --

HYZY: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- investors are not going to worry about it.

HYZY: That's correct. At least that's our deal.

JON HILSENRATH, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": What's your expectation for U.S. economic growth this year? And also for the rest of the world? There was so much talk in 2019 about a global slowdown then that narrative changed in 2020.

HYZY: No question about it. We have been on this narrative probable a little early. Six months ago we were talking about a fourth minimum mini- wave. The business cycle today is very different than what we knew. The business cycle's less boom-bust (ph). It's slower growing, less inflation, more liquidity higher debt over all, lower stock of interest rates, debt service ratios are manageable.

All of that puts together a much longer business cycle until the Fed makes a mistake. And they don't want to make a mistake but they tend to go too far. They almost did in 2018, some would argue they did. And then '19, they'd back that off.

Now remember, going into '19, which was really interesting here was they were going to hike four more times. They cut three -- that's a seven- change move offer the course of 12 months. That's very powerful.

Now we're heading into 2020 when liquidity is going up. So from our standpoint you can think about growth, our baseline forecast is 1.7 and that's probably too low.

When you think about what's going on in the first quarter, you should see a bottoming in global growth. In the back half of the year, the non-U.S. economies help support a little bit better growth.

HILSENRATH: And Let's not forget that federal spending, government spending is going through the roof right now. We're going to have a stronger dollar --

BARTIROMO: Peter Navarro said that's another leg to the stool. That that is actually driving our --

(CROSSTALKING)

HILSENRATH: Washington is pumping money into this economy. And we are also seeing it coming out of China too.

HYZY: No question. C plus I plus G and in the export market you put all of it together the 1.7 percent goes a lot --

HILSENRATH: There's a lot of G -- that is the government.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So you got the jobs number out this Friday. And we're on the doorstep of fourth quarter earnings. So the fourth-quarter earnings season begins next week with the major banks. Would you be buying stock ahead of these two major events.

HYZY: Yes, we'll be buying stocks on weakness. Through the year we see a few patterns developing through the year. After earnings a little bit of a pullback heading into primary season, et cetera.

And then into the summer months when the election risk starts to take up or get elevated at that point. Over the summer months, we see another pullback. Typical years have two or three pullbacks of 5 percent. We expect the classic pullbacks again this year notwithstanding what's going on in the Middle East, I would be buyer (ph) for that.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: But how are individual investors positioned for this, because last year nearly half a trillion dollars net flowed into bond funds when money, by billions and billions, was flowing out of equity funds both U.S. domestic focus and international. They're not just mutual but also exchange traded funds.

That doesn't seems -- it seems like someone is making a mistake. Are investors positioned for something bad this year? Or were they just -- making an error last year?

HYZY: You know, mathematics will tell you a lot of things and sometimes they tell you nothing because the flows out of mutual funds are almost being recycled back into ETF. So collectively when you look at it, you might argue it's net neutral in equity flows in general.

But to your point, it's a really good point, demographics are driving more fund flows into fixed income, simply because of the aging that is going on and the need to retool your asset allocations the other way. Plus the advent of new solutions and new products out there, that automatically rebalance portfolios into fixed incomes the older you get.

So put all of that together, the individual investor collectively looks like they're making mistakes but actually, what we are seeing is more money coming in at younger ages in some of the consumer accounts that we see, and consumer allocation at the lower levels, they're actually adding more to equities.

It's a very interesting dynamic. It's going to take years to play out.

BARTIROMO: And they're buying technology, right. You're looking at big tech in 2020 you say technology is not limited to just one industry anymore.

HYZY: That's a great point. We bucket traders too much in our industry but one of the greatest buckets is technology. Just the technology sector itself.

But if you look at all sectors, it's fraught with a lot of innovation across the board. So we would look at who is dominating tech across the sectors not just in that one sector.

(CROSSTALKING)

HILSENRATH: -- the United States or the rest -- are there any opportunities out there in the rest of the world right now?

HYZY: The emerging markets are another category that you envelope together. Parts of emerging markets that have the ability to withstand this movement from globalization to localization over the next few years are the areas you want to be.

If you think about Poland and Mexico that are targeted areas that are not going to be hurt as much as other emerging markets when you shift the supply chain. But yes, we are looking at upgrade opportunities in emerging markets --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

still slightly underweight and we're underweight non-U.S. in general but looking for upgrade --

(CROSSTALKING)

HILSENRATH: That's an interesting -- I'm sorry, I don't want to interrupt but --

BARTIROMO: Go ahead.

HYZY: Oh no.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I mean I just had a question in terms of is there any rhetoric from either side that is going on right now because this is a transitional year with politics. Is there any rhetoric from either side that kind of gives you pause in terms of how it would negatively affect the market?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Like how about if Elizabeth Warren gets up in the polls. Or Bernie Sanders looking like he's going to win. What happens to the markets then?

HYZY: At this particular time, it is so early in the process that there isn't anything right now that we can foresee that dents the economic picture at this point. We will obviously, reassess the further we get into the policy front, but as of right now we're our core base case is still very plain vanilla which we discussed before 1.7 say to 2 percent growth, 1.8 to 2 percent on the 10-year yield, 8 percent returns overall driven by real profits.

HILSENRATH: Do you get at all worried about corporate debt. Households are in good shape but there's a lot of corporate debt out there. And we're seeing some movement in some lower rated debt tat suggests there might be some cracks.

HYZY: If interest rates rise to a level driven primarily by inflation and not just flows out of fixed income pushing yours up. but if it's driven by inflation and it prompts a response by the fed that we are not prepared for, it would worry me because of the size of the absolute debt.

What doesn't worry me right now is the fact that the number one thing companies said they are going to do and the number one thing investors say they want companies to do is pay down debt.

BARTIROMO: Yes. So real quick before you go. Is there an index in ETF -- anything that you think our viewers might want to look at to invest alongside what you are saying right now? Give me one idea.

HYZY: Ok. So in terms of just -- just think about sectors for a second. The one sector that has tended to lead early stage recoveries and middle stage recoveries that we haven't seen up until the tail end of last year is financials. I would watch the financials very closely to give you a better feel for the overall market.

We like financials, we think the yield curve actually surprises people. stiffens a little bit, not greatly. But provides a little bit of tonic and the consumer is really leveraged so, the financial sector's very leveraged --

(CROSSTALKING)

BARTIROMO: But is this early stage -- this is late stage. I feel we were late stage.

MCDOWELL: It is but he is saying that the financials didn't not perform as they have historically.

BARTIROMO: So they're in an early stage.

BARTIROMO: Now that yield curve steepened after it inverted in the spring and then the middle of the year, so now you're finally getting some wind behind the backs of these financials.

HYZY: Great point absolutely. And I would argue because of what the Fed has done, we are potentially backing the early stage.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. We will hear from the banks next week --

Joining us right now is John Paul Mitchell Systems chairman and co-founder, the Patron Spirits co-founder billionaire John Paul DeJoria. It's great to see you -- sir. Thanks so much for being here -- John Paul.

JOHN PAUL DEJORIA, CO-FOUNDER, PATRON SPIRITS: Good morning -- Maria. Always a pleasure. Love from Austin, Texas.

BARTIROMO: So I want to kick it off with your sense of how things are going from a business standpoint, in terms of the economy, in terms of consumer demand out there -- how are you seeing things?

DEJORIA: We are very, very bullish. We see this economy continuing to grow this year. We know this in all areas that I'm involved in -- whether it's the spirits industry, whether it is hair care, cosmetics. All areas are growing and people are happy.

It seems also people are more satisfied with their opportunities in this world. There's more positive talk going on than there is negative talk. So I consider that all contributing to a good economy.

BARTIROMO: yes. I want to ask about the Spirits business in a minute because this is trend of less sugar, people are turning to vodka instead of wine. But then they go dry in January. So we'll talk about that in a second.

But let me he focus on the spiraling homelessness crisis because I know this is important to you.

DEJORIA: You bet. Very much.

BARTIROMO: Business wants to help. WE had the CEO of Cisco in recently, saying he's going to try to do what he can in San Francisco. But you look at some of these pictures, whether it is New York City, San Francisco, Chicago, L.A. -- the homelessness problem has gotten worse. What are businesses doing?

DEJORIA: Well to give an example of what we're he doing here in Austin, I think we've got the answer to it. We build a community called Community First through Mobile Loaves and Fishes. And what we did was we built 250 little houses.

And if you have been in a shelter -- I mean out of a shelter for at least one year where you're sleeping under a bridge on the street, you're the first people to come in. We only have three rules and we give you a little house. Those rules are: no drinking, no fighting, and no alcohol -- period.

You get the house. You pay $90 a month. Well, people say but some homeless have zero money, how can they forward $90 dollars a month.

If we give you something, just give it to you -- we give you a handout, you don't feel special. If you contribute, we gave you a hand up.

So what we do is this. We have wood shop, auto shop, metal shop. We have crafts going on. We have gardens going on, organic -- make organically better than the wealthy people eat in most cases.

So they have an income. Now they are able to pay that $90 a month rent, feel they're part of the community because we help them work and have extra money left over for other things.

It's working so well that we are now putting together phase two, which is another 400 homes. At the same time we are working with the city on a new program, to build a large unit for about 300 people. and those 300 homeless men, women, no matter what -- they come in there for shelter.

There'll be bathrooms. There'll be places to stay, and counselors to help them go to places like Mobile Loaves and Fishes or the next place to go to get out of the rut. In other words when people just throw money at it and feed it, it is not the thing to do. It's not the answer.

When we involve them in our community and this is all, by the way, done by volunteers, volunteers, volunteer money.

BARTIROMO: That's terrific.

DEJORIA: but it's working. Yes. And we have other states coming here to look at it and say my God it is working. So here we now take 250 people that wanted something, needed a handout and now they're contributing to society and paying taxes and cleaning their act up. and it is working.

And you go online, your wonderful listeners, and look it up under Mobile Loaves and Fishes -- Community or Community First. It is working and working well.

HILSENRATH: John Paul -- how do you explain what is going on here. On the one hand the economy is doing really well, it's growing really fast.

DEJORIA: Sure.

HILSENRATH: And yet, even in places like Austin, we're showing pictures, we have a homelessness problem that seems to be getting worse. How do you put that two and two together? How do you have an economy so strong that is also leaving so many people behind right now?

DEJORIA: what is taking place right now is it's not the haves have and the have-nots don't have. It's just that a lot of people because of rent, I am going to throw this back at rents, are going so high from the major cities. For $100 or $200 a month end up on the street there's now in between or how do you get back again.

So instead of here is a soup line how many facilities do we have -- how do we get you back again? How do we build proper housing?

I understand that for example Los Angeles, or even here in Austin. They want to spend millions of dollars to build hotels to house maybe 50 people. Well, one they are spending too much. And number two, you're housing somebody, you're putting band-aids on, you're not putting in something that gets them back to work.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

DEJORIA: There are so many jobs available right now, that take minimal training. That minimal training isn't available. In schools there was auto shop, wood shop, metal shop. That's where I went to school. I built a go-kart in, junior high school. It doesn't exist anymore.

When I graduate from high school many, many years ago you can immediately go into great paying job, a great paying job if you were trained in school. It is not there anymore. As the trades leave the school and those physical arts leave the school it means a lot of people that were trained before to do something don't have those jobs.

So big companies are right now, this is the truth, hiring people from outside the United States to fill the jobs, because the jobs are here but there are not enough qualified people in many cases --

BARTIROMO: What about some of the liberal policies in some of these cities. I'm just wondering if that is part of it because you are seeing, you know, cities like San Francisco, a sanctuary city. Cities like Los Angeles -- I mean that are really seeing the big brunt of this.

And then you've got this tax flight to Florida, Sunshine State has been gaining population, some extremely wealthy residents over the past years have gone to Florida. Major business leaders are seeking lower taxes.

So talk to us about policy, and its impact -- John.

DEJORIA: I would love -- I'd love to; and I'm going to give you Austin as an example. 25 years ago in Austin I moved here about 20 years ago. But 20 -- 25 years ago here in Austin you didn't have a bunch of panhandlers on the street, a bunch of homeless people. But you did have a lot of people they called hippy like that were selling flowers, selling trinkets on the street. Nice, clean people. All of a sudden we get rushed in the last 20, 25 years with homeless more and more and more and more. What are some of the things that contributed -- overregulation and over-licensing.

In Austin, Texas, you have to have several hundred dollars to buy a permit to sell something on the street -- a trinket, a lemonade. People that don't have any money can't come up with hundreds of dollars and the regulations and what you have to pay the city's board. So with all due respect regulations are great scenarios but the United States of America has become over-regulated.

I read an article recently about California. How it takes over a year to get a permit to build a house there.

BARTIROMO: Right.

DEJORIA: So of course, home builders have that extra expense on their hand. So I think what's happening is taxes and regulations are getting so high right now, it's taking middle class people out of a middle class life in many, many cases.

And talking a lot of homelessness so I think the city should take a look at their taxation. When it talks about California we have more people coming to Texas, and of course Florida and other states.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

DEJORIA: From New York and corporations because they are being over taxed. When you are overtaxed, they have to realize this -- no disrespect extreme liberals, ok. You have to understand this. When you overtax people, they are going to move. When you pay too much money away they're going to put it someplace else. It's not the answer.

BARTIROMO: So we are expecting USMCA to get the mark up today possibly passed the Senate this week or next week? ROGOFF: Well, first of all, the trade deal is much more important to Mexico than it is to the United States. I think the United States the big news is they passed something, they got something done. That really, you know, probably positively affects the psychology that when something really important is going on, it will happen. I think the effects on the U.S. economy are going to be pretty marginal.

There are some good things in it. Environmental standards protected a bit. The restrictions on manufacturing imports, I think are counterproductive.

And I think the risks that it is quite a bit higher than people are expecting, or at least equal to the odds of having a recession. But, you know, it seems like the most likely is the low twos at the moment,

ROGOFF: Well, we would have had a cycle and imports from China because I think a lot got front loaded, fearing the tariffs would be even higher. It's also sensitive to oil prices. I can't really read too much in it beyond that.

ROB SMITH, SPOKESPERSON, TURNING POINT USA: Now, I want to ask there are some people that think that both the Democrats and President Trump are winners with this USMCA getting best in going about that, what do you think?

ROGOFF: You know, it's so hard to know the effects of these -- this geopolitical uncertainty, usually, unless something really dramatic happens. It's actually not that great. But obviously, if Iran, you know, does something to block oil shipments from the Middle East, that would have a striking effect, if the U.S. were suddenly to be, you know, thrown into a war where it had to vastly raise expenditures, that would have an effect.

But I think at the moment, you know, they're hot spots all over the world. It's not entirely clear whether in the long run this cools it off or heats it up, because of course the Iranians were stepping up provocation against the U.S. And maybe that's all cool it off in the end, who knows.

HILSENRATH: Ken, we're 11 years into an economic expansion. What could end this thing and when?

It -- I don't think our chances of having a recession right now are any more than slightly elevated, I'd say in a normal year, 15 to 20 percent. Maybe they're 20 to 25 percent now. And they spend it, that certainly helping boost consumption, that seems likely to continue. I think, if the jobs numbers continue to be good, consumer optimism will be good and it will probably boost expenditure.

But of course, you know, the question is what's sustainable? And that -- that's I think the big issue if we shifted to a completely different regime. I think a lot of the policies that Warren and Sanders have said in the short run might well boost the economy but I'm not sure how good they'd be for long run productivity that would be much less clear.
