urn:contentItem:6012-1M51-DXH2-62HM-00000-00Chaos In Minneapolis; Riots, Looting And Arson Grips Minneapolis; Donald Trump Signs Social Media Executive Order; Interview with Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL); One In Four Michigan Coronavirus Deaths From Nursing Homes; Father Says Lockdowns To Blame For Son's Suicide; Russia Narrative Is Rapidly Falling Apart2020-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTMatt Gaetz, Brad Hunstable, Glenn Greenwald, Kendall QuallsNEWSDomestic052801cb.260Chaos In Minneapolis; Riots, Looting And Arson Grips Minneapolis; Donald Trump Signs Social Media Executive Order; Interview with Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL); One In Four Michigan Coronavirus Deaths From Nursing Homes; Father Says Lockdowns To Blame For Son's Suicide; Russia Narrative Is Rapidly Falling ApartTucker Carlson, Karen Scullin, David Webb, Marc Siegel, Mike Tobin

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: May 28th, 2020, but as always, "The Story" continues. So, we will see you right back here tomorrow night at seven o'clock. Thanks for joining us, everybody. Have a good night. Tucker is up next.

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

Anarchy grips parts of Minnesota at this hour, riders are burning cars and looting stores in neighborhoods across the Twin Cities, Minneapolis and St. Paul.

Meanwhile, lawmakers there seem too afraid to do anything to protect the public. We've got a lot more detail on what's going on there. We'll have it for you in just a minute.

But first tonight, we're joined by Fox Minneapolis's Karen Scullin for an update at the scene -- Karen.

KAREN SCULLIN, REPORTER, FOX MINNEAPOLIS: Well, we are outside the Third Precinct, where I'm happy to report at the moment, it is peaceful.

And if you notice, all the attention is turned away from the Third Precinct and actually on that van with there's a microphone set up. That's Mad Dads. They are a community peace group. They have a microphone. A lot of people stepping up right now offering messages of peace and unity and not violence.

So, kind of a change here. It was a little volatile earlier on. Right now though, although you can see the barricades in front of the Third Precinct leftover from last night put up today, we have a lot of windows that were smashed out last night.

But again, right now, the crowd is growing that it is peaceful at the moment. I can tell you a short while ago, maybe about an hour ago, just down the street, there was some sort of an incident or an assault it appeared and we were told that there was a stabbing and a couple of people were assaulted.

They called police for help. When police arrived at that time, the crowd started moving that way. They threw eggs. They threw water bottles. Police in that case responded with flashbangs and a round of teargas.

They did manage to get those victims off into the back of squad cars and left apparently or presumably to go to the hospital. That then dispersed.

There hasn't really been any kind of a situation between police and the crowd since then.

Behind me now you, can see the AutoZone. I'm sure you saw pictures last night of it up in flames. This is what's left. Obviously, burned to the ground along with a couple of apartment buildings.

There was a Wendy's that burned to the ground last night just behind there. I was told 16 structures in all did burn last night. Firefighters responded to 16 structure fires.

Over here real quick, we had some looting in the area, a lot of looting, actually. And you can see that the windows are boarded up all around this area here in the precinct. Obviously, these stores are closed.

But again, what we have right now is a peaceful moment, a big crowd, but a peaceful moment as speakers step up to the mic and say, hey, let's not have a repeat of last night. We'll send it back to you.

CARLSON: Karen Scullin for us in Minneapolis. Thanks so much.

If you were watching any of the coverage from Minneapolis today about what happened last night, you know perfectly well that what's happening on the streets there, no matter what it may look like, is actually a quest for justice.

It's long overdue search for answers by legitimately frustrated protesters who, if we are going to be honest about it, have been oppressed for so long they can no longer stand idle.

What you're seeing in Minneapolis is democracy in its purest form, effectively, it's a political rally. Here's was a representative scene last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is literally the craziest stuff I've ever seen right now. This is Target right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Now, wait a second, you may be thinking. That didn't look like a political rally. Those people look like looters. They were smashing cash registers with hammers to steal other people's money.

Well, yes, technically they were doing that. And yes, as a factual matter, they were smashing the cash registers because they had already stolen everything else in the store.

So no, it doesn't look like conventional political activism. But before you judge them, keep in mind, it could have been far worse. It's not like they were doing something immoral, like protesting Gretchen Whitmer's coronavirus lockdowns in Michigan. That would have been a different story.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOY REID, MSNBC HOST: Black people's right to protest is secondary to white people's right to be an armed protest with long guns, terrifying looking war weapons.

CHRIS HAYES, MSNBC HOST: This is how the protest of Floyd's death ended up. Police in riot gear, flooding the streets with teargas and shooting rubber bullets into the crowd.

Another example of how this pandemic has been a kind of black light, exposing all the inequalities in American life.

CHRIS CUOMO, CNN ANCHOR: That's the meme that's going around right now with the cops, with the black kid on the ground saying hello to the white guy in camo with the AK-47 and the mask who was protesting in Michigan.

That when it's white people with guns and they're out and they're angry and their faces with cops --

DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR: I didn't see any of that.

CUOMO: Everybody is civil.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It says if some people are accorded the rights of citizenship and other folks are just expected to be obedient.

Peaceful -- ended up in the state capitol, Craig, with automatic weapons and they were treated with kid gloves.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Oh, you see, it's not at all like those fascists in Michigan. In Minneapolis, there is a reason people are doing it. Legitimate reason, even the cash register smashers, they were simply smashing the cash register. So relax.

By the way, the cash registers deserved it anyway, as Joy Reid suggests on MSNBC, they're probably European cash registers and therefore complicit in oppression.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REID: Europeans came to this country to get away from being subjects of the kings in Europe. But what they did was they created for themselves sort of a kingdom, every man a king, but the subjects are black people.

These armed white men who can get armed up and walk into a state capitol and that's okay and the police are benign. They don't even act afraid.

But let black people show up and protest the death of an innocent black man, and suddenly, you know what, we need teargas. We've got to go full force.

Charlottesville, the same thing. The police were there to protect the people who were marching as Neo-Nazis not to protect the black people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So who watches Joy Reid, you may be wondering? Well, it turns out the people who run Minneapolis apparently watch Joy Reid.

As their city crumbled around them, local leaders huddled in deliberation. They emerged with a plan. They declared that racism is quote, "a national emergency."

CNN immediately trumpeted the development as if it were breaking news. Meanwhile, mobs in Downtown Minneapolis kept looting stores, kept burning. Normal people of all colors huddled indoors -- terrified.

No one bothered to explain how any of this was connected. How exactly does racism have anything to do with looting ATM machines or stealing PlayStations from Target? It's confusing.

What we do know is that riots are now acceptable because racism is a national emergency. That's the new standard. Okay. So now that we're in a state of national emergency, the question is, what is not acceptable? What's not okay? Anything?

Here's what some of the quote "protesters" were chanting last night in Minneapolis.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Shoot the white folk. Shoot the white folk.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So, you're not going to see that clip on CNN. How come? It is simple. Facts like this and there are a lot of them challenge the carefully constructed storyline that our leaders richly profit from.

Therefore those facts must be suppressed. For example, practically every day, we're told that white cops are a mortal threat to black men and some are obviously, it's what started this whole thing, a black man was killed by the police. It's awful.

But what are the national numbers on this? Well, actually, we know the answer. A study from last year found that white police officers were less likely to shoot and kill nonwhite suspects than nonwhite police officers were.

In any given year, police kill more white suspects armed and unarmed than black suspects. And that's a fact, by the way. It's not political propaganda. It's provably true.

Yet no one on television will ever say that because that fact threatens the scams they're working.

Eddie Glaude, Jr. might be the living embodiment of this phenomenon. If you've ever wondered whether yelling racist at the people you want things from it's an effective business plan, Eddie Glaude is living proof that indeed it is.

By regularly screaming racist, Glaude has been able to ride a mediocre academic career all the way to an endowed professorship at Princeton.

It's a job with such high pay, and so few actual requirements that Glaude can dress like a British Lord, and spend much of his day shuttling by limo between cable news hits.

Talk about a sweet gig.

As long as Eddie Glaude continues to denounce people as racist, the right people, he can probably keep that job forever. So naturally, Eddie Glaude has no interest in explaining how exactly racism makes people loot Target. It just does, okay, and if you disagree with that premise, you're a racist yourself. So shut up.

As Glaude told viewers in MSNBC, it's all about the quote, "context."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

EDDIE S. GLAUDE, JR., CHAIR OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AFRICAN-AMERICAN STUDIES, PRINCETON UNIVERSITY: Most human beings natural inclination when they feel wrong, when they feel put upon, when they're living under oppressed conditions is to lash out. And this is the history of the modern West, the history of the world, and actually, in some ways.

And so part of what we have to do is try to understand the context of what led to what happened --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Oh, the context and squint your eyes as you say "the context." Of course, there's a context to setting fire to McDonald's says Professor Glaude. It's interesting.

So, you've got to wonder how would Eddie Glaude, Jr. respond if something like this happened to him? If looters descended on his house, would Glaude gently described them as protesters, as they made off with his Hermes necktie collection?

If thugs with bandanas on their faces smashed the windshield of his BMW with rocks, would Eddie Glaude call the police? Or would calling the police be racist?

Just how long, in other words, could Edie Glaude maintain his fraudulent racial justice shtick in the face of the kind of violence that he routinely excuses on television? We're thinking not very long. It's just a guess.

Let's hope Eddie Glaude is never tested on that, certainly, anytime soon. Let's hope none of us are tested.

The problem with outbreaks of mob violence is you really have no idea where they're going next. You can't know. Sometimes they subside, often, they metastasize. They're unpredictable, and they are mortally dangerous, and that's why you don't encourage them.

In St. Paul, signs have appeared in store windows announcing this is a black-owned business. In other words, we're the right skin color. Spare us. What does that tell you?

Imagine if you saw a sign saying white owned business in windows. You would be horrified and you should be, you know, it was a race riot.

We've had a lot of those in this country through the years and there is nothing worse than that.

But Minneapolis has decided to just let their riot happen and damn the consequences.

Watch the city's Police Chief explain why he doesn't plan to do anything at all to stop rioters.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

QUESTION: So, what you're saying is it's too dangerous for police to directly confront the looters, so you've made the decision to maybe let that site go for now and focus on keeping the rest of the neighborhood as safe as possible?

CHIEF MEDARIA ARRADONDO, MINNEAPOLIS POLICE DEPARTMENT: Absolutely, our officers are being -- have been through several hours here, Molotov cocktails thrown at them, rocks and other projectiles. And so obviously their safety is paramount, and so I don't want them going into an area where they're at risk of harm themselves.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Obviously, the safety of officers is paramount announces the chief. The interviewer says nothing.

But in fact, it's not at all obvious. In fact, it's perfectly backward. Society's first concern is the safety of citizens, especially the weakest citizens. That's why we have police in the first place, to protect people who cannot protect themselves -- the public.

Not everyone wants to do that job and that's fine. Do something else. But we can't allow this.

Imagine if the Secret Service adopted the same attitude. Sorry, I can't protect the President today, too risky. How about the military? We'd love to repel the invasion, but unfortunately, we might get hurt, our apologies.

Things would fall apart. Things are falling apart in Minneapolis. And as they collapse, our leadership class seems thrilled. They're doing nothing to calm racial division. In fact, they're eagerly stoking it.

"The New York Times" wrote a piece just this morning with the title, "How White Women Use Themselves as Instruments of Terror." The subhead read this way, quote, "There are too many noosed necks, charred bodies and drown souls for them to deny knowing precisely what they are doing."

Wait a second. Them? What they are doing? Keep in mind, this didn't run in Louis Farrakhan's free weekly. This was "The New York Times" this country's most important newspaper, the high tempo of American liberalism.

"The New York Times" is telling you that every single person of a certain color and sex has a hand in genocide. They are stained by blood guilt. They are murderers, every one of them. What do you do to murderers? You know the answer.

It's hard to believe our leaders are actually talking like this, but they are, a lot and loudly and if they keep it up, things will not end well, and yet, they show no signs of slowing down.

Watch as two of CNN's leading lights get to the bottom of the national emergency we're living through. They've discovered who is responsible for it, one hundred percent responsible. They know who is guilty. Here's a hint, it's an entire racial group.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LEMON: It is not incumbent upon black people to stop racism, to stop this. It is incumbent upon people who hold the power in this society to help to do that, to do the heavy lifting, and guess who that is? Who is that, Chris?

CUOMO: White people.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: The funny thing is, as we often point out, these are the very same people who claim they're fighting your racism. Okay.

But the problem is much bigger this time than mere hypocrisy. We're very used to that. This problem is far more ominous. Here it is in three sentences.

There are 320 million of us in this country. A lot of us are very different from one another, yet we all have to live together. In fact, most of us want to live together. But suddenly our leaders are making that dangerously difficult.

David Webb hosts "Reality Check" with David Webb, and he joins us tonight. David, thanks so much for coming on.

I don't think anybody could watch the tape of the guy dying underneath that cop in Minneapolis and not feel sick and I'm in that category.

But I don't understand why at a volatile moment like this, the people to whom we look for guidance and wisdom are making the problem worse and intentionally making people hate each other. Why are they doing that?

DAVID WEBB, FOX NATION AND RADIO SHOW HOST: Tucker, you know, I watch you religiously. We work together and for the first time, I actually really felt a little bit down as you were going through your monologue and the points in the various positions.

But it goes right to your question. These are people who are not interested in dealing with the real issues in our society. This is a tragedy that should never have happened. We both know that, Americans know that. But they are using it.

They are race and poverty pimps who are using it to foster violence, the tearing down of society. And in fact, if they were successful, the tearing down of what we've done in this country, which is to evolve and advance as a culture that has overturned colonial racism and has rejected segregation and has opened up the doors to freedom for men, women, all ethnicities.

And here we are discussing it again as people burn their own communities. And it is a sad testament to many out there that are doing this.

You're talking about the cash register. How does that advance -- how does breaking and looting, burning advance your righteous cause and your righteous call for actual justice for George Floyd? How does it do that?

CARLSON: Exactly.

WEBB: It doesn't. And around the nation, we have people, major figures, many of whom you've mentioned, others that are jumping on board, whether it's rappers, public figures of some sort, who are calling from rioting, who are calling for more of this.

This is where society reaches a crux of a real challenge to itself, and I'm going to implore the people in Minneapolis, St. Paul, everywhere, please, think about what you're doing to your communities. Think about the examples in Ferguson on West Florissant and South Florissant Streets.

Think about what happened in Baltimore with Freddie Gray. Think about what has happened to those neighborhoods and what you've done to destroy your community while not achieving the level of justice you seek.

CARLSON: Some fraudulent Princeton Professor eggs them on. They're not coming to his house. In 1967, Detroit had one of the lowest black unemployment rates in the country, then they had riots -- race riots -- and then it became Detroit.

For these people to encourage that is really wrong, I would say. David Webb, thank you for your perspective. I appreciate it.

WEBB: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Those pictures by the way we showed you of the burning car, we just had up on the screen, that's happening right now.

We'll be watching the chaos in the Twin Cities throughout the hour, but back in Washington, the President has signed a new Executive Order that seeks to break Big Tech's control of speech online. Will it work? We will speak with a Member of Congress about that, next?

CARLSON: Well, the City of Los Angeles now requires all citizens to wear masks even when they go outside. There's no scientific evidence whatsoever that forcing people to wear masks outside prevents the spread of disease. None. No evidence. But whatever, the mayor commands it, he's God now. You have to.

But listen to the details on this order from so-called health authorities as reported in "The LA Times," we're quoting here, "If you must re-wear your cloth facemask covering before washing, wash your hands immediately after putting it back on and avoid touching your face." Think about that. What are they telling you?

They're telling you that your facemask is so dangerous you must wash your hands thoroughly after touching. It's like a bio weapon.

But then you're required to put that same terrifyingly dangerous facemask over your nose and mouth, and you're required to do this by law. Good luck, Los Angeles. You don't deserve this.

Back in Washington today, the President signed an Executive Order designed to stop censorship by the Big Tech companies online. The order comes two days after Twitter placed a fact check on two of the President's tweets that criticized universal mail-in voting as conducive to voter fraud. It is conducive to voter fraud, by the way, provably so, people have been convicted.

But Twitter called it a lie anyway. So, what does the President order do? Well, it redefines U.S. policy. It says explicitly, the government's position is to protect free speech on major social media platforms, good for them.

Toward that end, the White House will create a tool to let American citizens report cases of Big Tech bias to the D.O.J. and the F.T.C., the Federal Trade Commission for possible investigation.

Additionally, the Secretary of Commerce is ordered to petition the F.C.C. to propose new regulations that would expose tech companies to legal action if they remove content or ban users based on deceptive or dishonest grounds, or if they don't give users an adequate ability to contest the censorship they've suffered.

All of this is good. The question is, is it enough? If it comes to fruition, if the order does what it says it will, it will take some time. And of course, it could be instantly reversed and likely will be the second, a Democrat takes power and runs the administration.

So, what we need to fix this isn't an Executive Order, again, those are reversible, but laws which are passed by the Congress traditionally, and it should be.

The Communications Decency Act of 1996 is at the center of this. It's the reason that Big Tech is as powerful as it now is. Section 230 of that Act holds that -- we're quoting now -- "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider." What does that mean?

It means that the Big Tech companies, Facebook, Twitter, YouTube are not considered responsible for the content that appears on them. Because they're just platforms. They're not publishers. They can't be sued for libel if somebody posts something libelous on their services. They're considered neutral.

And that actually makes sense. We're in favor of that, if they remain neutral platforms, but they are not neutral platforms. They are publishers, the most powerful publishers in the world.

They fact check, as you've heard recently. Twitter routinely purges users simply for having the wrong political views.

Facebook has created an oversight board to decide what users are allowed to say. YouTube takes down videos if they question the decrees of local politicians.

This is political censorship, and it is taking place with the approval of the United States Congress. So, these are monopolies and they're conducting censorship. They're not neutral platforms putting out all information in the public's best interest.

Again, they're publishers curating content in the same way CNN does, MSNBC does, "The New York Times" does and Fox News does. But unlike any of those news organizations, these companies are immune from lawsuits, thanks to Section 230. That is corrupt.

It's an unfair business advantage. It empowers a handful of tech monopolies to the detriment of everyone else. It puts a small group of people in control of all human information in English, and it guts our constitutional liberties.

So at this point, after years of this Congress taking payoffs from these people and ignoring it, now is the time to stop it.

If these businesses want to be treated as neutral platforms, they must be neutral platforms, otherwise, they should get their carve-out yanked from them immediately.

Congressman Matt Gaetz of Florida is a lawmaker pushing to do that, to change Section 230, we're grateful for that. He joins us tonight.

Congressman, thanks so much for coming on. So why hasn't this happened already? They're violating the intent of the law.

REP. MATT GAETZ (R-FL): Well, Big Tech buys off Congress so as to maintain special privileges that local newspapers and television stations don't enjoy. That's why the President's Executive Order today is one very important next step because if we just wait around, Big Tech will steal this election from Donald Trump and from the American people.

In 2016, we won three Rust Belt states by a point each, and that was when nobody thought Donald Trump could win in 2020. We've lost the element of surprise, and so we have to be as aggressive as they are.

That means bills like Senator Hawley and I have filed have filed to change Section 230, so as to out these entities as publishers and not the unbiased platforms they are, it means an Executive Order like the President has issued, but it also means getting the other elements of government to enforce existing law.

The Federal Election Commission needs to get off their duff. Twitter is interfering with an election. I heard Democrats say for three years that Russia was interfering with an election. That was a hoax.

We have domestic election interference going on right now. I'll be filing a complaint with the Federal Election Commission tomorrow because of what they have done to President Trump and as a voter, I have the standing to do it.

And President Trump should call for a decision on the Federal Election Commission questions that are before them so that these tech companies get flushed out of the bushes.

CARLSON: But Mark Zuckerberg argues and in this, I agree with him, that you don't want to see Section 230 revoked. You want people to have liability from libel suits, because then you can have much more information, a free flow of information.

So, what do you do -- so you probably don't want to change that, but you have to make these companies live up to the promise they made to be neutral platforms. How do you force them to do that? How should Congress do that? And again, why haven't they?

GAETZ: Well, again, Big Tech companies have a tremendous amount of influence over Congress. It's one reason why I don't take their PAC money or anyone else's Federal PAC money, but on the question of what has to be done, I agree with you.

But if someone is going to assert that they are a non-biased, neutral platform, we should not just take that as an article of faith. We actually have to have investigative work done, transparency, disclosures.

If we're going to give these folks the privileges that you would give a public utility company, maybe we need to start regulating tech like the public utilities as they are.

CARLSON: That's exactly -- that's it. You know, you hate to think it's going to come down to this, I think it's going to have to. They have too much power.

Congressman, thanks so much for that. Good to see you.

GAETZ: Thank you.

CARLSON: Well, the press, of course, has covered every death from coronavirus, which they should do. They've given almost no attention to the explosion of suicides and overdoses caused by the lockdowns in response to the coronavirus.

It's a huge problem. It's real.

We have an important story from someone who has been touched by it personally after the break.

Then we'll head back to Minneapolis live where rioters are continuing to destroy one of this country's great cities, unimpeded. That's just ahead.

CARLSON: The savage beating of a 75-year-old service veteran at Detroit's Westwood Nursing Center was horrifying to watch. We played the tape for you. But the story becomes even worse when you know the details.

According to his father, 20-year-old Jaden Hayden was transferred by the state to that facility after he tested positive for the coronavirus -- to a nursing home. How could that have happened?

The Great Dr. Marc Siegel of NYU Langone hospital joins us tonight. Doctor, thanks so much for coming on. Simple question. How could this happen?

DR. MARC SIEGEL, FOX NEWS MEDICAL CONTRIBUTOR: Tucker, let me tell you something. I'll tell you how this can happen.

Governor Whitmer, who we've talked about on the show here of Michigan has one of the most supreme lockdowns, serious lockdowns in the entire country. The Upper Peninsula of Michigan has only 110 COVID-19 cases, 110, and it's a beautiful recreational area, yet it's under extreme lockdown. And the congressman in the state has been complaining and writing op-eds about this, and that's how severe the lockdown is.

But not nursing homes. Nursing homes are not locked down at all. In fact, Bob Gordon, who is the Head of Health and Human Services in Michigan announced just this week, we just heard this breaking news that there's over 1,200 deaths in in nursing homes at facilities like it in Michigan.

Over 25 percent of the deaths in Michigan from COVID-19 have occurred in nursing homes, and this is being underreported. It's actually a lot more than that.

How can this happen? Well, we've talked on the show here about Governor Cuomo of New York having this rigid order that forced nursing homes to take back people who are COVID-19 positive, to admit people who are COVID-19 positive, and that's since been partly withdrawn.

Here in Michigan, well, guess what? Governor Whitmer actually issued an Executive Order on May 20th, Tucker, May 20th, saying that nursing homes can't prohibit people from being admitted who are COVID-19 positive and they have to just put them in a unit for COVID-19 positive patients.

This is a disgrace, and it's going to cause COVID-19 to spread through these nursing homes and we're going to see way more deaths.

One final thing about this, Tucker, that I want to say to Governor Whitmer directly. I put my boat in the water right before Memorial Day and I went out on the sea and I had an incredible thoughtful revealing experience and something came to me, and I want to say to her, when your husband's boat goes in the water, go out on the sea and rethink this nursing home policy and rescind this Executive Order, please, before we see thousands of more unnecessary deaths -- Tucker.

CARLSON: I think that's wise advice. Being outside does help you think clearer. There's no doubt about that. Doctor, thank you so much.

SIEGEL: She needs it. Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Well, deaths from this virus have been heavily covered over the past few months. We've covered them in some detail on this show. We should.

But far less attention, virtually none really has been given to the hidden agony resulting from months of lockdown. As of tonight, one-third of all Americans show signs of depression or anxiety or both according to the Census Bureau.

Americans fired from their jobs are isolated from friends and family are dying in unprecedented numbers. They're dying from suicides, overdose, and other deaths of despair.

Unfortunately, nobody understands that as well as Brad Hunstable does. He's a business owner, a graduate of West Point. It's hard even to say this, but he just lost his son, Hayden, who was locked down as well.

Brad Hunstable joins us tonight. Mr. Hunstable, thanks so much for coming on and it is very hard to have this conversation. But you wanted to come because you thought it was important for the public to hear this and I agree with you. So, tell us the effect you think these policies had on your family.

BRAD HUNSTABLE, BUSINESS OWNER AND WEST POINT GRADUATE: Well, Tucker 41 days ago, right above my head, my young 12-year-old boy, three days before his 13th birthday, took his life.

Hayden was a normal kid. He wasn't depressed. He loved athletics. And I created a video that since has gone viral, and I said the COVID virus, he died of the COVID virus. He didn't die of the coronavirus, but he died certainly because of the COVID virus.

The isolation has created what I believe and what I worried and what I am warning every parent in America tonight. An emotional tsunami is sweeping this nation and I'm very concerned about it.

CARLSON: Flesh it out a little bit if you would, the isolation, which I mean, that's how we punish prisoners, by isolating them. Tell us the effects, you think, that it is having on children.

HUNSTABLE: Let me start by giving you some stats that I bet most people in America don't even know, and I certainly didn't know this prior to my son passing away.

The second leading cause of death in the United States for 10 to 14-year- olds is suicide. The second leading cause of death of 15 to 24-year-olds is suicide, 25 to 34-year-olds is suicide.

Eighty percent, some studies have shown, up to 80 percent of all suicides were impulsive suicides and that means they made the decision very, very, very quickly. Seventy percent of those made the decision within the last hour, 40 percent within the last five minutes.

And so when you combine that with social isolation, which is not the human condition, we set up a perfect storm in a scenario where we have what is taking place all across the country and Tucker, I've got the numbers to support it.

CARLSON: You and I have been talking, you said that you've seen, it hasn't just touched your family, hurt your family so much, but people around you in your community, people you know have also gone through moments likes this.

HUNSTABLE: We've lost another one in my small town, almost lost a third one in my small town. We lost four in the town of Jay, four teens. One kid hung himself from the goalpost of the football stadium.

And so there's probably a total of six around my town. My West Point, buddy, unfortunately, passed away through that through self-harm method just last week.

This is a tragedy and the stigma around suicide, I know it can be taboo. I know people don't want to talk about it because they don't know what to say.

But I've been screaming for them as loud as I can because conversations matter. We have to talk about it.

What we've done in the past hasn't worked. It's time to try something different. And I implore every American, every parent out there, if you're working on your patio outside, grab your son, your daughter, take them to Home Depot. Take your kid on a walk.

Conversations matter and we're in a heightened state of anxiety.

CARLSON: Amen. People are not meant to be alone and the bloodless technocrats don't get that, but it's true. It's always true. Always. Brad Hunstable, thank you for telling that story.

HUNSTABLE: Thank you.

CARLSON: Pretty brazen. Well, the Russia collusion story has been essentially debunked for more than a year. But even now, the basis for that investigation, which was the so-called hacking of the D.N.C. remains intact. The Russians did it. But did the Russians do it? That's the core question. We'll assess that after the break.

Plus the Minneapolis riots are ongoing. We'll tell you what's happening when we return.

CARLSON: So, where did the Russia collusion story come from? The beginning? Well, it was rooted as a story in the publication of thousands of leaked e- mails from the D.N.C., a lot of which embarrassed the Hillary campaign.

That set of e-mails and e-mails from John Podesta's personal Gmail account were stolen by Russia and given to WikiLeaks in London. That was the story. Anyone who questioned it was attacked.

When we asked a question about it, Adam Schiff himself suggested we must be Russian agents.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Look right into the camera and say I know for a fact that the government of Vladimir Putin was behind the hacks of John Podesta's e-mail.

REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D-CA): Absolutely. The government of Vladimir Putin was behind the hacks of our institution and the dumping of information --

CARLSON: Of John Podesta's e-mail.

SCHIFF: Not only in the United States but also in Europe.

CARLSON: Of John Podesta's e-mail. Okay, you're not -- you know what you're dodging the question.

SCHIFF: And Tucker --

CARLSON: Look and say, I know they did John Podesta's e-mails. They hacked those.

SCHIFF: And I think that Ronald Reagan will be rolling around in this grave --

CARLSON: You can't -- Ronald Reagan, finally, Ronald Reagan.

SCHIFF: You're carrying water for the Kremlin.

CARLSON: I am not carrying water for -- you're making --

SCHIFF: It's you and the President-elect --

CARLSON: Look, you're a sitting Member of Congress on the Intel Committee and you can't say they hackers --

SCHIFF: You're going to have to move your show to RT -- Russian Television.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So he wouldn't say it because you knew it wasn't true, and now there's accumulating evidence that in fact, it wasn't true. The Russia didn't do that. That's not a defense of Russia. It's a fact.

The F.B.I. never directly inspected the D.N.C. servers for evidence of Russian hackers. They took the word of a private company called CrowdStrike. You know the story.

But in recently declassified house testimony, CrowdStrike's CEO admitted there was no proof that Russia did that. Julian Assange, by the way, who runs WikiLeaks has always denied that Russian hackers got him the e-mails.

And yet, here's something very odd. The Mueller team never interviewed Julian Assange. He wanted to be interviewed. They didn't. Why not? Well, you know why? Because the truth was never the point.

Glenn Greenwald co-founded "The Intercept." We disagree, probably on a lot politically, but from day one, he has taken an enormous amount of abuse for being skeptical of the Russia story, and we're happy to have him on tonight.

So Glenn, I can't get past this one question, and I think you probably know more about this than anybody I know personally.

The question of how did these e-mails get from the D.N.C. server to WikiLeaks? And it's starting to look like maybe they were leaked by a D.N.C. staffer who was mad that the Hillary campaign was taking -- was siding with the D.N.C. Do you think that's how they got there? How did they get to WikiLeaks?

GLEN GREENWALD, CO-FOUNDER, THE INTERCEPT: I don't think we know and that was the point all along. The original heresy in Russiagate that got many of us expelled from the halls of decent liberal company was questioning the declaration from security state agencies who have a history of lying, declaring definitively that Russia was behind the hacks.

And all you had to do in order to be declared a heretic in journalism was to say, you know what, I'd actually like to see some evidence for that. I'm not saying it couldn't have happened or that it is beyond the realm of possibility, Russia does stuff like that, so does the U.S.

But before I believe that, I'd actually like to see some evidence from that and we got the kinds of responses that you just showed with Adam Schiff accusing you of being a Kremlin pawn or a Kremlin asset or disloyal or unpatriotic for having wanting to see the evidence.

And as it turns out, there is some relevant evidence to that question, but it was hidden for years until just recently, namely, that the head of CrowdStrike, the only entity that was actually able to examine the servers admitted in closed hearings before the House that there is no concrete evidence that Russia in his words, exfiltrated those e-mails.

He said, there's indicia of it. There's circumstantial evidence for it, but there's no hard concrete scientific evidence the way we were told for three years existed and that we all had to unquestioningly swallow.

And the amazing thing is, very few people have talked about that incredibly important aspect of that testimony that utterly erodes the core initial premise of the entire three years that dominated our political discourse, the media has just utterly ignored it.

CARLSON: Very quickly. By the way, if you hear dogs barking in the background, Glenn Greenwald runs a dog shelter out of his house.

GREENWALD: It's because Tucker has a lot of dogs who poorly behaves.

CARLSON: I love that. Very quickly, Julian Assange is at the very center of the story. His organization, WikiLeaks ran these e-mails which started the whole story. Why didn't Mueller or Andrew Weissmann or why didn't somebody from the investigation ever interview him?

GREENWALD: Well, I mean, I think it's reasonable to say that even if Julian Assange believes that the people who gave him those e-mails weren't part of the Russian government that isn't at all proof that it wasn't the Russians who did the hacking. They could have easily done the hacking and then given it to somebody else to give to Julian Assange.

But if you're investigating a crime in which e-mails end up illicitly with a group that publishes them. Obviously, you want to talk to that person about how they got them and who gave it to them.

CARLSON: Exactly. Exactly.

GREENWALD: And he was pleading to be interviewed and they just refused.

CARLSON: They interviewed a woman I know because she was at a party with someone else they were interested in. But they didn't interview Julian Assange. It tells you everything.

Glenn Greenwald, great to see you. And God bless you for helping those dogs.

GREENWALD: Great talking to you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Thanks. Well, it's been two days but rioting and looting are still underway in the Twin Cities, Minneapolis and St. Paul. We have live reporting from that scene, next.

CARLSON: Well, rioters or as CNN calls them, questions seekers, are continuing to devastate the Twin Cities tonight. Fox's Mike Tobin is there for us tonight live. Mike, how is it?

MICHAEL TOBIN, FOX NEWS SENIOR CORRESPONDENT: Well, we've already seen it going off just a little bit here. If you go behind me and look right behind me, you can move that.

Look right behind me, there is a car fire that's underway right now and something we ought to be careful about. Someone just took the fire extinguisher with all those compressed gases and threw it inside of that car fire. So, that guy clowning around to a gang signs has put himself at a bad position.

Earlier, right in this area, the teargas came out. And that's because someone was hurt and they were on the ground and the paramedics were trying to get some space to work and people were throwing things at the paramedics and the police tried to get them some space. That's when the teargas came out there.

So, not any big thing so far, just a little bit of skirmishes and a car fire. You saw the press conference from the Hennepin County Attorney, from the U.S. Attorney saying the investigation is underway with the backing of the President, with the backing of the U.S. Attorney General, and it's just not fast enough for these people.

They want to see arrests. They want to see convictions. They don't want to wait for a process -- Tucker.

CARLSON: Yes. Thanks, Mike. It's called mob justice, by the way. Just a car burning in the middle of a street in a major American city. No problem. It's America.

Kendall Qualls is a Republican running for Congress in the third District of Minnesota and he joins us tonight. Mr. Qualls, thanks so much for coming on.

What do you make of the response to this? I'm sure like most people, you were upset by the video of a man dying, most people were, but the response from the leaders in your area to what's happening in Minnesota. What do you make of it?

KENDALL QUALLS (R), MINNESOTA CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Sure, Tucker, first of all, thank you for having me on. I wish it was on better circumstances.

CARLSON: Me, too.

QUALLS: You know, I think all of us outraged by what we saw in the video. Our hearts are out for George Floyd and his family. But there's three things really that need to be, you know, clarified, if you will for what's happening on the ground.

Three different groups of people. One, we have the legitimate protesters that were outraged and want justice for George Floyd and his family. They were black and white from the community, equally outraged.

Then you have people you don't see in those videos. These are the most vulnerable citizens right now, senior citizens in those homes, a lot of single mothers that want to actually have a different direction for their children, want them to escape those kind of communities, much like I did, when -- I used to live in Harlem, New York.

And then lastly, you have the mob, if you will, taking advantage of the situation. They're not there to protest. They're being mislabeled as protesters and they are not. They're taking advantage of the situation for their own gain, and you know cause chaos and anarchy.

CARLSON: And their agenda. I think that's such a smart and important point. I think all of us are for a legitimate political protest. We defend it all the time, even when we disagree with it.

But this isn't for -- some of these people about the death of this specific man, it is about something different, isn't it?

QUALLS: Unfortunately so. You know, I've seen this and what the tragedy of this is. Now, the whole topic of discussion, the attention is driven toward these activities, and not justice for George Floyd, his memory, his family, and it's all about now law and order.

And that we've seen this consistently in this country. And if anything, for those people that we never hear about, we never get to hear their voice, those that are the most vulnerable. They're wishing something like taking control of the city or taking control of the situation would have happened much sooner.

CARLSON: Yes, this won't make lives better for a lot of people, that's for sure. We have a long, long history of moments like this really hurting people who don't have a lot.

So Kendall Qualls, thank you so much for coming on tonight. Great to see you.

QUALLS: Thank you.

CARLSON: We are completely out of time, indeed about three seconds away. The Great Sean Hannity takes over for 9:00 p.m. from New York.

urn:contentItem:601H-DX71-DY2B-1009-00000-00Chaos now his biggest threat2020-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisAll EditionsPg. 9Chaos now his biggest threatMICHAEL GOODWIN

For most of Donald Trump's brief political career, chaos has been his friend. He draws energy from an endless storm of difficulties and controversies that would send most presidents into the fetal position.

Critics and supporters alike compare his presidency to a reality television show, one that always ends with the leading man getting the last word. From Russia, Russia, Russia to Ukraine and impeachment, Trump's time in the White House has been a continuing roller-coaster ride between danger on one side and disaster on the other.

A political Houdini, he has always escaped and emerged stronger in victory, but now comes the biggest test. He is in the middle of his re-election campaign just as public disorder is expanding and accelerating, leaving many Americans extremely unsettled and fearful about the future.

For the president, the outcome could turn on the question of how much chaos is too much chaos. And whether independent voters will abandon him because of Trump fatigue.

Elections, of course, are referendums on the incumbent and, pre-pandemic, the president was in the driver's seat. The economy was roaring, unemployment was at record lows and he finally appeared to be comfortable with his White House team.

Democrats couldn't find either an issue to run on or a strong nominee. Socialism was a loser and one shooting star after another flamed out - remember the glory days of Pete Buttigieg? - until only a confused Joe Biden was left standing. His infirmities are so obvious that Barack Obama didn't endorse him until there were no other options.

Yet the nation's mood has shifted sharply in the last three months, with the pandemic roiling the political and economic landscape and giving Biden a fresh chance at victory. Dems and their media handmaidens are determined to hang every one of the 100,000 deaths around Trump's neck and use the enormous job losses as an indictment against the president's ­tenure.

If that weren't trouble enough for the incumbent, just as the pandemic begins to recede from the headlines, other disturbances already are beginning to eclipse it.

Start with the most sudden and sensational: the brutal death of a black man in Minneapolis at the hands of police officers, one of whom was charged with murder.

Protests quickly turned into ­riots, looting and arson, the National Guard is patrolling the streets and sporadic anti-police violence is spreading. The prospect looms of a long, hot summer of urban unrest.

Simultaneously, the president's simmering feud with Big Tech also erupted. Twitter dropped its pretense of political neutrality to fact check Trump tweets, effectively declaring that it has joined the resistance and has no intention of dropping its long-standing bias against the president and his supporters.

The double standards are glaring, but Big Tech is now too big to scare. Threats from Iranian mullahs and far-left nut jobs who talk of assassinating Trump are acceptable posts, but the president of the United States gets the bum's rush.

Trump, naturally, hit back hard, drafting an executive order calling on the Federal Communications Commission to end the social media giants' legal liability exemptions. The result could alter the handful of companies that dominate digital advertising and personal communications.

While many on the left have longed for tighter regulation of the tech firms, they also clamor for restricting Trump's access. His embrace of regulation will probably turn them into ardent defenders of the legal exemptions and give them an opportunity to claim, falsely, that he wants to abolish the First Amendment.

The final bombshell of last week may turn out to be the most consequential. Clearly exasperated by China and sensing he was being tested, the president moved to pull the US out of the World Health Organization as part of the confrontation over the coronavirus. Among other moves, he also condemned China's crackdown on Hong Kong and vowed to end favored treatment to the former British colony, saying the Communist Party had broken the treaty where it pledged to allow greater freedoms there.

Throughout his Rose Garden statement, the president's language was notably more harsh toward China than it has been. He offered no warm words of friendship for President Xi Jinping, nor did he express confidence that the first part of the renegotiated trade deal would remain intact.

China is not backing down, with a top general threatening to attack Taiwan, which would force America to defend its tiny ally or see it crushed. China also threatened Australia's economy, warning of a trade calamity if it sides with the United States.

Recall that China showed its willingness to meddle in our elections by commissioning anti-Trump articles and ads in the Midwest before the 2018 midterms, and we should expect more of the same as it tries to help defeat Trump and elect Biden. US officials also say Chinese hackers are engaged in cyber attacks against us and our allies.

It's possible that some or all of these developments will break in Trump's favor. The riots and looting, for example, are not likely to move independent voters to Biden, and becoming China's preferred candidate might hurt him more than it helps. At the least, it will bring new focus to Hunter Biden's business there.

Similarly, the opposition of Big Tech can be seen as another example of the media abandoning their standards to defeat Trump, and thus energize his supporters.

Still, the growing sense of chaos in the country is an unpredictable factor that could determine the November outcome. In about five months, we will know if President Houdini can pull off another great escape.

Donald Trump. [Getty Images]

urn:contentItem:5WVX-FV81-DY0W-402Y-00000-00Chaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex Tillerson2017-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisChaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex TillersonLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody. Happy Thursday. Thanks for being with us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, February 2. Here are your top stories, 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Groundhog's Day. Chaos on campus. Violent protesters breaking out last night at UC Berkeley over a speech from a conservative editor, forcing the cancellation of the event.

Broken windows, as you see flames. The university and local residents frustrated as agitators got in the way of the first amendment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I support free speech. See what he had to say (INAUDIBLE) ideas talked about and it just got shut down by a bunch of people (INAUDIBLE) protester masks.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not a proud day for this campus on the free speech movement. The violence is deplorable. And there's really nothing to be proud about because of what happened here tonight.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The outrage coming up this morning.

Meanwhile, President Trump's cabinet adding another member. Former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson has been confirmed and sworn in as secretary of state. This happened late yesterday.

Even his other nominees are still facing roadblocks. We've got all the details on the confirmations coming up.

A strong earnings report from Facebook to tell you about. The social media giant posting better than expected fourth-quarter revenue. Profit also was above expectations. We're breaking down those numbers.

Looking ahead to Amazon's results there out tonight after the close. Facebook shares going to be up this morning.

Checking the broader markets. Take a look at where we're looking at this morning and it is a pullback. Some selling underway. The Dow Industrials expected to be down about 50 points today. NASDAQ down about 20 points after a gain yesterday.

In Europe, muted action this morning. Take a look at the major indices throughout the Eurozone and you'll see mixed performance. The FT 100 is up a third of a percent. That's 22 points higher.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board to report. Take a look, Asian markets finished like this. Still a holiday in China. Shanghai Composite closed but the Nikkei average in japan down one in a quarter percent. The worst performer throughout the Asian markets.

One football fan scoring the ultimate ticket, Super Bowl seats for life. The details coming up.

And then a great American tradition. It's Groundhogs Day today. Will Punxsutawney still see his shadow? We will take you to Pennsylvania later this hour live where the crowd are lining up. It is incredibly packed right there this morning at this time.

All that coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former Goldman Sachs partner and New York Times best-selling author Peter Kiernan is with us. And Maverick PAC national co-chair, Morgan Ortagus. Good to see you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Great to see you. Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I love being here every morning.

BARTIROMO: Groundhogs Day. Every day is Groundhogs Day.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Hey, we got Rex Tillerson confirmed. We'll see who else is on the docket.

MCDOWELL: Betsy DeVos having some problems with two republican senators saying they're not going to vote for her. And so now it looks -- it looks split 50 votes for the republicans and so she's hanging on by a thread.

BARTIROMO: I didn't expect that coming to republicans.

MCDOWELL: I did not either.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll talk about that this morning. Big show ahead. Forbes media chairman and former republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is in the house. We got to talk to with him about tax reform.

Plus, the former republican presidential candidate and former Minnesota governor Tim Pawlenty with us this morning.

The chief investment officer of CalPERS Ted Eliopoulos is with us this morning. We're going to find out how he's allocating capital.

And Ohio congressman who ran against Nancy Pelosi from minority leader. Tim Ryan is with us. Big show.

Plus, former NFL star, Jack Brewer as well. Stick around. Stay right there. We've got a big program ahead.

We kick it off right now with a wave of destruction blanketing the University of California campus Berkeley campus last night. Protesters rallying against the planned speech by the school by Breitbart news editor Milo Yiannopoulos. Rioter's started fires, they broke windows. They confronted police. Ultimately causing the talk to be canceled.

Fox News' Tucker Carlson spoke with Milo Yiannopoulos last night about the chain of events and protesters spoke out as well. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MILO YIANNOPOULOS, NEWS EDITOR, BREITBART: This evening we got into the building, started preparing for the show and people started arriving in black clothes then masks. They were clearly carrying concealed shields weapons and things. And then stuff being thrown at the building. There were rocks being thrown. Various other things being thrown out of the building. Eventually the ground floor was breached and I was evacuated.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We have the right to defend ourselves. And so this shutting this down Milo Yiannopoulos and doing whatever is necessary to do that is our right to self-defend.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's one thing to protest someone's right to come here and speak, but it's another thing to create this much amount of destruction and violence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Incredible. Peter Kiernan, what's your reaction here? I mean, UC Berkeley was -- I know -- regardless it is a left-leaning university. But isn't this the place where typically students go and say we want free speech and look what they do to somebody who's about to give a speech?

PETER KIERNAN, FORMER PARTNER, GOLDMAN SACHS: Yes. I have to say, this man is on the campus tour from hell. He got cancelled a couple of weeks ago at UC Davis and the University of New Mexico. They just find the group that was hosting in $3,500.

He is somebody who is basically being rejected everywhere. And I thought universities were places of free and open exchange of ideas.

MCDOWELL: Not in modern history they're not. These left-wing individuals -- and this is throughout the college system in this country and it's led by professors quite frankly, that they preach tolerance, but breed intolerance. They're breeding intolerance in the name of tolerance. That is what is so both ironic and repugnant in what's going on here.

BARTIROMO: why is that do you think? I just had this conversation last night. Why are the academics spewing this liberalism and they are just -- I mean, even when you look at the day after the election when Donald Trump won. They're telling students of different narrative than actually what happened. Why?

ORTAGUS: I think it's just another symptomatic case where you say they're completely out of touch with the American people, right? The university job especially getting tenure. It's a bunch of groupthink, I think in a lot of occasions and these are not people that are out working some job nine to five or trying to make ends meet. They had pretty cushy jobs at universities. It's like being in the government, right, where you can get fired.

What was really interesting to me though about the Berkeley situation, Maria, is that Berkeley invited at the time President Ahmadinejad from Iran when he was being incredibly provocative to the U.S.

MCDOWELL: Death to America.

ORTAGUS: And death to America. So you do not see the type of protests for him that you saw last night.

Also, Milo is not without controversy. So this is -- let's not pretend that he doesn't -- he stoked the flames a bit so he does it as well.

MCDOWELL: It doesn't matter though because they said this on this program when it comes to liberal protests, whether marches here to protest police brutality for example. Defending the first amendment means tolerating and allowing for speech that even you find repugnant and offensive. That's what the first amendment is about. It not about this.

And it shows liberal left wing distortion of what's really going on when you hear the young woman saying, we have the right to defend ourselves. Your right is to not listen to what Milo Yiannopoulos has to say

BARTIROMO: Yes, don't go. Don't show up.

MCDOWELL: But stop acting like this is a physical attack on you.

BARTIROMO: Why are you defending yourself?

KIERNAN: I think when it's all said and done, the safe space mentality, we're going to protect the students from the real world or from the world that's different from what they believe. When those students get out into the real world, they'll find that there are a plurality of points of view, even though as they never heard on campus.

And if campuses are meant to create great leaders in the future, what are they training them for if they don't have full exposure to the voices?

MCDOWELL: They shut down freedom of expression. They're shutting down the first amendment and at the same time, and you can't say this enough. This college campuses -- because of these professors, they've become a breeding ground for anti-Semitism in this country.

And they're giving people cover to basically preach hatred of Jews and it's disgusting.

BARTIROMO: it's disgusting. And where is the president? Where is the president of the university to come out and stop this and show some leadership? Have we heard from anybody at the leadership?

KIERNAN: Well, it's interesting, in UC Davis the chancellor did say something that was not condoning of this, but that's a talk. Where is the action and he chose from the day-to-day activity? Why aren't you opening your doors to contrary points of view?

BARTIROMO: That's a great point. Really a great points this morning on this.

I want to turn to immigration because President Trump's administration is considering an executive order that would take a closer look at visa programs for foreign workers in the U.S. This according to "The Wall Street Journal" this morning.

Morgan, your take on this. For Trump, it would be another promise fulfilled in keeping jobs in America, frankly.

ORTAGUS: I would like -- first of all, clearly, our immigration system needs reform. I think people on both sides of the aisles are honest with themselves. What I would like prefer to see over an executive order is that the president work with congress on comprehensive reform. And the reason is that President Obama have seen this firsthand.

When you issue all of these executive orders, they can easily be done. And so one of the problems over the past eight years, one of the reason President Obama was not effective is because he didn't work with congress to push this legislation through.

So I like the idea of this. I think we need reform. I would like them to see him go to congress, get a comprehensive play. Get something codified and delude that can't be undone the minute the next president comes in.

MCDOWELL: The tech industry particularly is upset about this, about the going after the H-1B visas for highly skilled workers.

And I would argue on the other hand of that. In fact, the CEO of GoDaddy was writing that there are currently 500,000 unfilled high skilled I.T. in computer science jobs.

If you want American companies to create more jobs, then you want the best and brightest minds from around the world living here and creating ideas and products that are then American-owned. So I would argue that this is critical importance.

We need to reform the education system quite frankly if you want Americans to fill this jobs. In the interim, you want to support great American businesses.

BARTIROMO: Which is why those CEOs of those technology companies are putting together a letter to send to President Trump to obviously review everything you just said, having the crux of the issue.

KIERNAN: I think they want it so bad. About a million people immigrate here every year. I think we should take 50,000 or 60,000 of those H-1B visas and sell them for $50,000. And if the high-tech companies want those people so bad to fill those slots, sell them. We could raise a billion dollars a year, do that for five years. That's how you find your fixing of the education system. I think there's an opportunity --

BARTIROMO: How are you going to sell them though? Are you getting best students in that way?

KIERNAN: I think what you do as I say, we're going to give you a slot. We'll sell to you for $50,000. If you want one of those H-1 visas, you pay.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK.

KIERNAN: For 50,000. We still have a million people coming in here with free of charge, no issue. But if we're going to turn this into a commercial partnership, let's really do it.

ORTAGUS: This is certainly be a discussion tomorrow with the president because he has CEOs that he's put on in his Business Roundtable that are meeting with him tomorrow. It's reported, I think that Elon Musk and the Uber CEO among others will be at the meeting. So I know that this will be --

MCDOWELL: Sadly not the Americans living here to fill these highly skilled jobs.

BARTIROMO: Well, that goes back to education because they don't have the skillsets required.

Meanwhile, President Trump tweeted this last night about his predecessor's decision to take in refugees from Australia. He writes this. Do you believe it? The Obama administration agreed to take thousands of illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal."

This coming after Trump reportedly clashed with the Prime Minister of Australia. Malcom Turnbull last night during a phone call about this matter, calling it, "the worst deal ever."

He accused Turnbull of looking to export the next Boston bombers. Now, there's a lot of media reporting about this morning, Peter, that they had a tense call. Do you predict this change in the U.S. relationship with Australia? And how important was this call? And how impacts --

KIERNAN: Well I think it was cable setting. We're basically getting started, but have you been to Australia? I mean, there's plenty of rooms to take a few thousand --

BARTIROMO: They won't take them, by the way.

KIERNAN: And the problem is why are they dishing their problem to us? I think it was very right and appropriate for the president to say, we're going to level set. The relationship now has changed.

MCDOWELL: Or do it as a dumb deal.

BARTIROMO: I know.

ORTAGUS: The call happened on Saturday too and that was after the rollout of the executive order would bungled. I think even the administration has acknowledged that.

So he's probably on edge given the fact that it's been a rough weekend.

But the one thing that we have to say is the Australian prime minister reiterated the special relationship. We work incredibly closely with the Australians. Anytime we go to war and in intelligence matters. It's an important relationship.

MCDOWELL: These refugees are in offshore detention centers right now in Australia. And if it's a deal that President Obama inked with Australia, it's up to the new president to decide whether it's in our best interest.

BARTIROMO: Do we know when that deal was inked? Remember, President Obama was doing so much in the final twilight days of his administration? We'll get the answer for you.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, rumors in retail. The long time CEO of Macy's is stepping down. Now there's talk the struggling retailer may put itself up for sale. Macy's on sale.

And then this little piggy had none. Bacon lovers fearing a shortage of their favorite pork product. Why a price hike might be in store. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Two staffers are being held hostage at a Delaware maximum-security prison this morning. Lauren Simonetti on headlines now. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi. Good morning, Maria. Two Delaware department of correction employees have been held hostage since last night, as inmates remained in an hour's long standoff with police.

This incident began when four employees at the correctional center were taken hostage yesterday morning. One DOC staff member was released four hours later, another shortly before 8:00 P. M.

In a call to the News Journal in Wilmington, one inmate reportedly cited President Donald Trump as the reason for the hostage situation saying because of Trump, he quote, "knows the institution is going to change for the worse."

Well, an attorney representing state inmates says complaints have increased in the past year from inmates about substandard medical care in poor record-keeping.

Big news in business world. A reported sale from Macy's is on the table. Longtime CEO Terry Lundgren stepping down as the head of the largest U. S. department store within the next few months. That's the report.

In an attempt to avoid more shakeup, Lundgren is reportedly considering a sale of Macy's. Macy's share in the past year are down about 30 percent. But this morning if you check out this board, they're up about four percent on the news.

And Nielsen mobile insights ranks T-Mobile number one in customer service satisfaction. The company beating up Verizon and AT&T as the company to most likely be recommended as well. This comes after T-Mobile offers to covers sales tax on new smartphones.

The deal will give customers more than 11 percent off of a phone's price if they're using a prepaid MasterCard.

All right. I love this story because I love to look at the video. For bacon lovers out there. Reports of frozen pork belly inventories reaching their lowest level in 50 years. Rest assured.

Earlier this week, we had a story that that was going to happen. But claims of these bacon shortages are unsupported. Meat processors are however paying 30 percent more than they did just a few months ago and that increase might show up shortly at supermarkets.

But for now, bacon prices are holding steady. And the USDA reports a pound of bacon averages actually 11 percent less than they did just back in 2015, Maria. So there you have it. Good morning and that's hogwash.

BARTIROMO: I like it. I'm glad you got dead end.

Breaking news right now, Lauren. We want to show everybody what Donald Trump has been tweeting. The president just tweeted this moments ago. If UC Berkeley does not allow free speech and practices violence on innocent people with a different point of view, no federal funds?"

Wow, the president is pretty aggressive in terms of coming out and saying, look, there are consequences for what you're doing. No federal funding?

MCDOWELL: I think that President Trump was watching Fox and Friends first this morning because Todd Starnes was on and had like a one-minute, two- minute commentary. That's exactly what Todd Starnes said on Fox and Friends first roughly an hour ago.

So I'm not saying that the president is getting his ideas from Mr. Starnes, but it's exactly what Todd was talking about.

BARTIROMO: This is a big issue though. How much money are we talking about in terms of what the federal government could hold back for university? We don't have those numbers.

ORTAGUS: When you at the pictures that you're showing of the protest, it looks pretty violent. So I think that Berkeley would argue. We cancel that to keep the students safe. Because it's incredibly violent. You saw fires and just watch it for yourself.

BARTIROMO: How does he get that out of control? Where is the leadership to stop it from getting out of control and putting things on fire at a university?

KIERNAN: Yes. I think it could become a lot calmer. If you look at how UC Davis handle it, they just canceled it. That's a better way to go

If you take the Internet category, to use Snapchat as an example, there's 164 public Internet companies between a billion and $10 billion dollar market cap, only nine of them have a growth rate of greater than 30 percent. ELIOPOULOS: Well, it's very difficult spot for investors right now because you have to prepare for some divergent outcomes is -- are we having inflationary environment going forward or continue to have a deflationary environment? There is no one portfolio that's going to be maximized in each of those environment. So, for CalPERS, we have such a dominate equity position in our portfolio, almost 48 percent of the portfolio today. We have bought some inflation protective securities and repositioned the portfolio as well as commodities in the run-up to the election.

BARTIROMO: In terms of 48 percent in equities, is that through index funds, ETFs or specific names?

ELIOPOULOS: Sure, yes

BARTIROMO: You're going to move in-house as pensions cut fees.

We have added a new allocation to actually opportunistic credit, to new credit strategy, structured credit, private, we think that's an opportunity for the future. And that bringing -- we have that talent in-house, we have active fixed income managers within our staff that are able to execute those strategies with confidence.

In the private market much is a much tougher assessment whether you can bring in-house, those strategies, and we're not sure right now on the private equity side that we could effectuate a strategy to compete with the external managers that are our partners that have done extraordinarily well for us overtime. The fees are high but the returns and the performance net of all those fees have been quite robust, and persistent for over 20 years for now -- for us now. So, it is a very important calculus to try and adjust the external internal model internally.

ELIOPOULOS: You have to keep those promises, so the key to make sure you price them and you save for them in order to keep those promises for the long term.
