urn:contentItem:5MT1-D2V1-JBHT-D050-00000-00Chaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex Tillerson2017-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisChaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex TillersonLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody. Happy Thursday. Thanks for being with us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, February 2. Here are your top stories, 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Groundhog's Day. Chaos on campus. Violent protesters breaking out last night at UC Berkeley over a speech from a conservative editor, forcing the cancellation of the event.

Broken windows, as you see flames. The university and local residents frustrated as agitators got in the way of the first amendment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I support free speech. See what he had to say (INAUDIBLE) ideas talked about and it just got shut down by a bunch of people (INAUDIBLE) protester masks.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not a proud day for this campus on the free speech movement. The violence is deplorable. And there's really nothing to be proud about because of what happened here tonight.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The outrage coming up this morning.

Meanwhile, President Trump's cabinet adding another member. Former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson has been confirmed and sworn in as secretary of state. This happened late yesterday.

Even his other nominees are still facing roadblocks. We've got all the details on the confirmations coming up.

A strong earnings report from Facebook to tell you about. The social media giant posting better than expected fourth-quarter revenue. Profit also was above expectations. We're breaking down those numbers.

Looking ahead to Amazon's results there out tonight after the close. Facebook shares going to be up this morning.

Checking the broader markets. Take a look at where we're looking at this morning and it is a pullback. Some selling underway. The Dow Industrials expected to be down about 50 points today. NASDAQ down about 20 points after a gain yesterday.

In Europe, muted action this morning. Take a look at the major indices throughout the Eurozone and you'll see mixed performance. The FT 100 is up a third of a percent. That's 22 points higher.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board to report. Take a look, Asian markets finished like this. Still a holiday in China. Shanghai Composite closed but the Nikkei average in japan down one in a quarter percent. The worst performer throughout the Asian markets.

One football fan scoring the ultimate ticket, Super Bowl seats for life. The details coming up.

And then a great American tradition. It's Groundhogs Day today. Will Punxsutawney still see his shadow? We will take you to Pennsylvania later this hour live where the crowd are lining up. It is incredibly packed right there this morning at this time.

All that coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former Goldman Sachs partner and New York Times best-selling author Peter Kiernan is with us. And Maverick PAC national co-chair, Morgan Ortagus. Good to see you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Great to see you. Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I love being here every morning.

BARTIROMO: Groundhogs Day. Every day is Groundhogs Day.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Hey, we got Rex Tillerson confirmed. We'll see who else is on the docket.

MCDOWELL: Betsy DeVos having some problems with two republican senators saying they're not going to vote for her. And so now it looks -- it looks split 50 votes for the republicans and so she's hanging on by a thread.

BARTIROMO: I didn't expect that coming to republicans.

MCDOWELL: I did not either.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll talk about that this morning. Big show ahead. Forbes media chairman and former republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is in the house. We got to talk to with him about tax reform.

Plus, the former republican presidential candidate and former Minnesota governor Tim Pawlenty with us this morning.

The chief investment officer of CalPERS Ted Eliopoulos is with us this morning. We're going to find out how he's allocating capital.

And Ohio congressman who ran against Nancy Pelosi from minority leader. Tim Ryan is with us. Big show.

Plus, former NFL star, Jack Brewer as well. Stick around. Stay right there. We've got a big program ahead.

We kick it off right now with a wave of destruction blanketing the University of California campus Berkeley campus last night. Protesters rallying against the planned speech by the school by Breitbart news editor Milo Yiannopoulos. Rioter's started fires, they broke windows. They confronted police. Ultimately causing the talk to be canceled.

Fox News' Tucker Carlson spoke with Milo Yiannopoulos last night about the chain of events and protesters spoke out as well. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MILO YIANNOPOULOS, NEWS EDITOR, BREITBART: This evening we got into the building, started preparing for the show and people started arriving in black clothes then masks. They were clearly carrying concealed shields weapons and things. And then stuff being thrown at the building. There were rocks being thrown. Various other things being thrown out of the building. Eventually the ground floor was breached and I was evacuated.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We have the right to defend ourselves. And so this shutting this down Milo Yiannopoulos and doing whatever is necessary to do that is our right to self-defend.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's one thing to protest someone's right to come here and speak, but it's another thing to create this much amount of destruction and violence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Incredible. Peter Kiernan, what's your reaction here? I mean, UC Berkeley was -- I know -- regardless it is a left-leaning university. But isn't this the place where typically students go and say we want free speech and look what they do to somebody who's about to give a speech?

PETER KIERNAN, FORMER PARTNER, GOLDMAN SACHS: Yes. I have to say, this man is on the campus tour from hell. He got cancelled a couple of weeks ago at UC Davis and the University of New Mexico. They just find the group that was hosting in $3,500.

He is somebody who is basically being rejected everywhere. And I thought universities were places of free and open exchange of ideas.

MCDOWELL: Not in modern history they're not. These left-wing individuals -- and this is throughout the college system in this country and it's led by professors quite frankly, that they preach tolerance, but breed intolerance. They're breeding intolerance in the name of tolerance. That is what is so both ironic and repugnant in what's going on here.

BARTIROMO: why is that do you think? I just had this conversation last night. Why are the academics spewing this liberalism and they are just -- I mean, even when you look at the day after the election when Donald Trump won. They're telling students of different narrative than actually what happened. Why?

ORTAGUS: I think it's just another symptomatic case where you say they're completely out of touch with the American people, right? The university job especially getting tenure. It's a bunch of groupthink, I think in a lot of occasions and these are not people that are out working some job nine to five or trying to make ends meet. They had pretty cushy jobs at universities. It's like being in the government, right, where you can get fired.

What was really interesting to me though about the Berkeley situation, Maria, is that Berkeley invited at the time President Ahmadinejad from Iran when he was being incredibly provocative to the U.S.

MCDOWELL: Death to America.

ORTAGUS: And death to America. So you do not see the type of protests for him that you saw last night.

Also, Milo is not without controversy. So this is -- let's not pretend that he doesn't -- he stoked the flames a bit so he does it as well.

MCDOWELL: It doesn't matter though because they said this on this program when it comes to liberal protests, whether marches here to protest police brutality for example. Defending the first amendment means tolerating and allowing for speech that even you find repugnant and offensive. That's what the first amendment is about. It not about this.

And it shows liberal left wing distortion of what's really going on when you hear the young woman saying, we have the right to defend ourselves. Your right is to not listen to what Milo Yiannopoulos has to say

BARTIROMO: Yes, don't go. Don't show up.

MCDOWELL: But stop acting like this is a physical attack on you.

BARTIROMO: Why are you defending yourself?

KIERNAN: I think when it's all said and done, the safe space mentality, we're going to protect the students from the real world or from the world that's different from what they believe. When those students get out into the real world, they'll find that there are a plurality of points of view, even though as they never heard on campus.

And if campuses are meant to create great leaders in the future, what are they training them for if they don't have full exposure to the voices?

MCDOWELL: They shut down freedom of expression. They're shutting down the first amendment and at the same time, and you can't say this enough. This college campuses -- because of these professors, they've become a breeding ground for anti-Semitism in this country.

And they're giving people cover to basically preach hatred of Jews and it's disgusting.

BARTIROMO: it's disgusting. And where is the president? Where is the president of the university to come out and stop this and show some leadership? Have we heard from anybody at the leadership?

KIERNAN: Well, it's interesting, in UC Davis the chancellor did say something that was not condoning of this, but that's a talk. Where is the action and he chose from the day-to-day activity? Why aren't you opening your doors to contrary points of view?

BARTIROMO: That's a great point. Really a great points this morning on this.

I want to turn to immigration because President Trump's administration is considering an executive order that would take a closer look at visa programs for foreign workers in the U.S. This according to "The Wall Street Journal" this morning.

Morgan, your take on this. For Trump, it would be another promise fulfilled in keeping jobs in America, frankly.

ORTAGUS: I would like -- first of all, clearly, our immigration system needs reform. I think people on both sides of the aisles are honest with themselves. What I would like prefer to see over an executive order is that the president work with congress on comprehensive reform. And the reason is that President Obama have seen this firsthand.

When you issue all of these executive orders, they can easily be done. And so one of the problems over the past eight years, one of the reason President Obama was not effective is because he didn't work with congress to push this legislation through.

So I like the idea of this. I think we need reform. I would like them to see him go to congress, get a comprehensive play. Get something codified and delude that can't be undone the minute the next president comes in.

MCDOWELL: The tech industry particularly is upset about this, about the going after the H-1B visas for highly skilled workers.

And I would argue on the other hand of that. In fact, the CEO of GoDaddy was writing that there are currently 500,000 unfilled high skilled I.T. in computer science jobs.

If you want American companies to create more jobs, then you want the best and brightest minds from around the world living here and creating ideas and products that are then American-owned. So I would argue that this is critical importance.

We need to reform the education system quite frankly if you want Americans to fill this jobs. In the interim, you want to support great American businesses.

BARTIROMO: Which is why those CEOs of those technology companies are putting together a letter to send to President Trump to obviously review everything you just said, having the crux of the issue.

KIERNAN: I think they want it so bad. About a million people immigrate here every year. I think we should take 50,000 or 60,000 of those H-1B visas and sell them for $50,000. And if the high-tech companies want those people so bad to fill those slots, sell them. We could raise a billion dollars a year, do that for five years. That's how you find your fixing of the education system. I think there's an opportunity --

BARTIROMO: How are you going to sell them though? Are you getting best students in that way?

KIERNAN: I think what you do as I say, we're going to give you a slot. We'll sell to you for $50,000. If you want one of those H-1 visas, you pay.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK.

KIERNAN: For 50,000. We still have a million people coming in here with free of charge, no issue. But if we're going to turn this into a commercial partnership, let's really do it.

ORTAGUS: This is certainly be a discussion tomorrow with the president because he has CEOs that he's put on in his Business Roundtable that are meeting with him tomorrow. It's reported, I think that Elon Musk and the Uber CEO among others will be at the meeting. So I know that this will be --

MCDOWELL: Sadly not the Americans living here to fill these highly skilled jobs.

BARTIROMO: Well, that goes back to education because they don't have the skillsets required.

Meanwhile, President Trump tweeted this last night about his predecessor's decision to take in refugees from Australia. He writes this. Do you believe it? The Obama administration agreed to take thousands of illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal."

This coming after Trump reportedly clashed with the Prime Minister of Australia. Malcom Turnbull last night during a phone call about this matter, calling it, "the worst deal ever."

He accused Turnbull of looking to export the next Boston bombers. Now, there's a lot of media reporting about this morning, Peter, that they had a tense call. Do you predict this change in the U.S. relationship with Australia? And how important was this call? And how impacts --

KIERNAN: Well I think it was cable setting. We're basically getting started, but have you been to Australia? I mean, there's plenty of rooms to take a few thousand --

BARTIROMO: They won't take them, by the way.

KIERNAN: And the problem is why are they dishing their problem to us? I think it was very right and appropriate for the president to say, we're going to level set. The relationship now has changed.

MCDOWELL: Or do it as a dumb deal.

BARTIROMO: I know.

ORTAGUS: The call happened on Saturday too and that was after the rollout of the executive order would bungled. I think even the administration has acknowledged that.

So he's probably on edge given the fact that it's been a rough weekend.

But the one thing that we have to say is the Australian prime minister reiterated the special relationship. We work incredibly closely with the Australians. Anytime we go to war and in intelligence matters. It's an important relationship.

MCDOWELL: These refugees are in offshore detention centers right now in Australia. And if it's a deal that President Obama inked with Australia, it's up to the new president to decide whether it's in our best interest.

BARTIROMO: Do we know when that deal was inked? Remember, President Obama was doing so much in the final twilight days of his administration? We'll get the answer for you.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, rumors in retail. The long time CEO of Macy's is stepping down. Now there's talk the struggling retailer may put itself up for sale. Macy's on sale.

And then this little piggy had none. Bacon lovers fearing a shortage of their favorite pork product. Why a price hike might be in store. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Two staffers are being held hostage at a Delaware maximum-security prison this morning. Lauren Simonetti on headlines now. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi. Good morning, Maria. Two Delaware department of correction employees have been held hostage since last night, as inmates remained in an hour's long standoff with police.

This incident began when four employees at the correctional center were taken hostage yesterday morning. One DOC staff member was released four hours later, another shortly before 8:00 P. M.

In a call to the News Journal in Wilmington, one inmate reportedly cited President Donald Trump as the reason for the hostage situation saying because of Trump, he quote, "knows the institution is going to change for the worse."

Well, an attorney representing state inmates says complaints have increased in the past year from inmates about substandard medical care in poor record-keeping.

Big news in business world. A reported sale from Macy's is on the table. Longtime CEO Terry Lundgren stepping down as the head of the largest U. S. department store within the next few months. That's the report.

In an attempt to avoid more shakeup, Lundgren is reportedly considering a sale of Macy's. Macy's share in the past year are down about 30 percent. But this morning if you check out this board, they're up about four percent on the news.

And Nielsen mobile insights ranks T-Mobile number one in customer service satisfaction. The company beating up Verizon and AT&T as the company to most likely be recommended as well. This comes after T-Mobile offers to covers sales tax on new smartphones.

The deal will give customers more than 11 percent off of a phone's price if they're using a prepaid MasterCard.

All right. I love this story because I love to look at the video. For bacon lovers out there. Reports of frozen pork belly inventories reaching their lowest level in 50 years. Rest assured.

Earlier this week, we had a story that that was going to happen. But claims of these bacon shortages are unsupported. Meat processors are however paying 30 percent more than they did just a few months ago and that increase might show up shortly at supermarkets.

But for now, bacon prices are holding steady. And the USDA reports a pound of bacon averages actually 11 percent less than they did just back in 2015, Maria. So there you have it. Good morning and that's hogwash.

BARTIROMO: I like it. I'm glad you got dead end.

Breaking news right now, Lauren. We want to show everybody what Donald Trump has been tweeting. The president just tweeted this moments ago. If UC Berkeley does not allow free speech and practices violence on innocent people with a different point of view, no federal funds?"

Wow, the president is pretty aggressive in terms of coming out and saying, look, there are consequences for what you're doing. No federal funding?

MCDOWELL: I think that President Trump was watching Fox and Friends first this morning because Todd Starnes was on and had like a one-minute, two- minute commentary. That's exactly what Todd Starnes said on Fox and Friends first roughly an hour ago.

So I'm not saying that the president is getting his ideas from Mr. Starnes, but it's exactly what Todd was talking about.

BARTIROMO: This is a big issue though. How much money are we talking about in terms of what the federal government could hold back for university? We don't have those numbers.

ORTAGUS: When you at the pictures that you're showing of the protest, it looks pretty violent. So I think that Berkeley would argue. We cancel that to keep the students safe. Because it's incredibly violent. You saw fires and just watch it for yourself.

BARTIROMO: How does he get that out of control? Where is the leadership to stop it from getting out of control and putting things on fire at a university?

KIERNAN: Yes. I think it could become a lot calmer. If you look at how UC Davis handle it, they just canceled it. That's a better way to go

BARTIROMO: When we come back, what is in a name? How Elon Musk is rebranding Tesla motors after closing a new deal.

And then we've got an eye on earnings this morning. Facebook beating expectations last night. Wall Street's looking for Amazon to deliver next. We've got the growth story on Amazon coming up. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets looking lower this morning. But Facebook certainly one to watch. Take a look at the shares this morning. The company reporting a strong fourth quarter last night, easily topping analysts' expectations.

Company's revenue up a staggering 51 percent year-over-year in the quarter. It was not all good news for the company though. Jury sided against his Oculus brand in a lawsuit ordering it to pay $500 million to game maker ZeniMax.

Joining us "Wall Street Journal" chief economic correspondent, Jon Hilsenrath on that. Jon, good morning to you.

JON HILSENRATH, CHIEF ECONOMIC CORRESPONDENT, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good morning, Maria. It's all about tech yesterday and today. We've got Amazon coming up later. And it looks like they're going to pump out blowout numbers too.

It's amazing to me that you have companies like Facebook and Amazon which are such a huge scale already. Amazon with almost 1.9 billion users around the world and it's pumping out 51 percent revenue growth numbers. To be that big and growing that fast is just really transformative.

BARTIROMO: You're right. And we're talking about Amazon a lot because it is incredibly successful. Look at the stock today and look at the business getting into all different industries. What do you think, Peter?

KIERNAN: Well, it's interesting, isn't it? That the very month that Amazon takes over from Macy's as the number one seller of apparel, there's a changing in the guard there.

And the thing that strikes me is Amazon went public exactly 20 years ago and that stock is up 42,000 percent.

BARTIROMO: Since the IPO?

some of it is probably going to have to be physical structure, some of it maybe drones, some of it may be electronics, some of it maybe more human resources. urn:contentItem:5WRR-09P1-JBHT-D374-00000-00Chaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex Tillerson2017-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:50ZLexisNexisChaos on Campus with Berkeley Protests; U.S.-Australia Relations Tense?; Macy's Sale Rumored; Delaware Hostage Situation; Rex TillersonLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good morning, everybody. Happy Thursday. Thanks for being with us this morning.

I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, February 2. Here are your top stories, 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Groundhog's Day. Chaos on campus. Violent protesters breaking out last night at UC Berkeley over a speech from a conservative editor, forcing the cancellation of the event.

Broken windows, as you see flames. The university and local residents frustrated as agitators got in the way of the first amendment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I support free speech. See what he had to say (INAUDIBLE) ideas talked about and it just got shut down by a bunch of people (INAUDIBLE) protester masks.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's not a proud day for this campus on the free speech movement. The violence is deplorable. And there's really nothing to be proud about because of what happened here tonight.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The outrage coming up this morning.

Meanwhile, President Trump's cabinet adding another member. Former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson has been confirmed and sworn in as secretary of state. This happened late yesterday.

Even his other nominees are still facing roadblocks. We've got all the details on the confirmations coming up.

A strong earnings report from Facebook to tell you about. The social media giant posting better than expected fourth-quarter revenue. Profit also was above expectations. We're breaking down those numbers.

Looking ahead to Amazon's results there out tonight after the close. Facebook shares going to be up this morning.

Checking the broader markets. Take a look at where we're looking at this morning and it is a pullback. Some selling underway. The Dow Industrials expected to be down about 50 points today. NASDAQ down about 20 points after a gain yesterday.

In Europe, muted action this morning. Take a look at the major indices throughout the Eurozone and you'll see mixed performance. The FT 100 is up a third of a percent. That's 22 points higher.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board to report. Take a look, Asian markets finished like this. Still a holiday in China. Shanghai Composite closed but the Nikkei average in japan down one in a quarter percent. The worst performer throughout the Asian markets.

One football fan scoring the ultimate ticket, Super Bowl seats for life. The details coming up.

And then a great American tradition. It's Groundhogs Day today. Will Punxsutawney still see his shadow? We will take you to Pennsylvania later this hour live where the crowd are lining up. It is incredibly packed right there this morning at this time.

All that coming up this morning.

And joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former Goldman Sachs partner and New York Times best-selling author Peter Kiernan is with us. And Maverick PAC national co-chair, Morgan Ortagus. Good to see you.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-CHAIR, MAVERICK PAC: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Great to see you. Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN HOST: I love being here every morning.

BARTIROMO: Groundhogs Day. Every day is Groundhogs Day.

MCDOWELL: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Hey, we got Rex Tillerson confirmed. We'll see who else is on the docket.

MCDOWELL: Betsy DeVos having some problems with two republican senators saying they're not going to vote for her. And so now it looks -- it looks split 50 votes for the republicans and so she's hanging on by a thread.

BARTIROMO: I didn't expect that coming to republicans.

MCDOWELL: I did not either.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We'll talk about that this morning. Big show ahead. Forbes media chairman and former republican presidential candidate Steve Forbes is in the house. We got to talk to with him about tax reform.

Plus, the former republican presidential candidate and former Minnesota governor Tim Pawlenty with us this morning.

The chief investment officer of CalPERS Ted Eliopoulos is with us this morning. We're going to find out how he's allocating capital.

And Ohio congressman who ran against Nancy Pelosi from minority leader. Tim Ryan is with us. Big show.

Plus, former NFL star, Jack Brewer as well. Stick around. Stay right there. We've got a big program ahead.

We kick it off right now with a wave of destruction blanketing the University of California campus Berkeley campus last night. Protesters rallying against the planned speech by the school by Breitbart news editor Milo Yiannopoulos. Rioter's started fires, they broke windows. They confronted police. Ultimately causing the talk to be canceled.

Fox News' Tucker Carlson spoke with Milo Yiannopoulos last night about the chain of events and protesters spoke out as well. Listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MILO YIANNOPOULOS, NEWS EDITOR, BREITBART: This evening we got into the building, started preparing for the show and people started arriving in black clothes then masks. They were clearly carrying concealed shields weapons and things. And then stuff being thrown at the building. There were rocks being thrown. Various other things being thrown out of the building. Eventually the ground floor was breached and I was evacuated.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: We have the right to defend ourselves. And so this shutting this down Milo Yiannopoulos and doing whatever is necessary to do that is our right to self-defend.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It's one thing to protest someone's right to come here and speak, but it's another thing to create this much amount of destruction and violence.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Incredible. Peter Kiernan, what's your reaction here? I mean, UC Berkeley was -- I know -- regardless it is a left-leaning university. But isn't this the place where typically students go and say we want free speech and look what they do to somebody who's about to give a speech?

PETER KIERNAN, FORMER PARTNER, GOLDMAN SACHS: Yes. I have to say, this man is on the campus tour from hell. He got cancelled a couple of weeks ago at UC Davis and the University of New Mexico. They just find the group that was hosting in $3,500.

He is somebody who is basically being rejected everywhere. And I thought universities were places of free and open exchange of ideas.

MCDOWELL: Not in modern history they're not. These left-wing individuals -- and this is throughout the college system in this country and it's led by professors quite frankly, that they preach tolerance, but breed intolerance. They're breeding intolerance in the name of tolerance. That is what is so both ironic and repugnant in what's going on here.

BARTIROMO: why is that do you think? I just had this conversation last night. Why are the academics spewing this liberalism and they are just -- I mean, even when you look at the day after the election when Donald Trump won. They're telling students of different narrative than actually what happened. Why?

ORTAGUS: I think it's just another symptomatic case where you say they're completely out of touch with the American people, right? The university job especially getting tenure. It's a bunch of groupthink, I think in a lot of occasions and these are not people that are out working some job nine to five or trying to make ends meet. They had pretty cushy jobs at universities. It's like being in the government, right, where you can get fired.

What was really interesting to me though about the Berkeley situation, Maria, is that Berkeley invited at the time President Ahmadinejad from Iran when he was being incredibly provocative to the U.S.

MCDOWELL: Death to America.

ORTAGUS: And death to America. So you do not see the type of protests for him that you saw last night.

Also, Milo is not without controversy. So this is -- let's not pretend that he doesn't -- he stoked the flames a bit so he does it as well.

MCDOWELL: It doesn't matter though because they said this on this program when it comes to liberal protests, whether marches here to protest police brutality for example. Defending the first amendment means tolerating and allowing for speech that even you find repugnant and offensive. That's what the first amendment is about. It not about this.

And it shows liberal left wing distortion of what's really going on when you hear the young woman saying, we have the right to defend ourselves. Your right is to not listen to what Milo Yiannopoulos has to say

BARTIROMO: Yes, don't go. Don't show up.

MCDOWELL: But stop acting like this is a physical attack on you.

BARTIROMO: Why are you defending yourself?

KIERNAN: I think when it's all said and done, the safe space mentality, we're going to protect the students from the real world or from the world that's different from what they believe. When those students get out into the real world, they'll find that there are a plurality of points of view, even though as they never heard on campus.

And if campuses are meant to create great leaders in the future, what are they training them for if they don't have full exposure to the voices?

MCDOWELL: They shut down freedom of expression. They're shutting down the first amendment and at the same time, and you can't say this enough. This college campuses -- because of these professors, they've become a breeding ground for anti-Semitism in this country.

And they're giving people cover to basically preach hatred of Jews and it's disgusting.

BARTIROMO: it's disgusting. And where is the president? Where is the president of the university to come out and stop this and show some leadership? Have we heard from anybody at the leadership?

KIERNAN: Well, it's interesting, in UC Davis the chancellor did say something that was not condoning of this, but that's a talk. Where is the action and he chose from the day-to-day activity? Why aren't you opening your doors to contrary points of view?

BARTIROMO: That's a great point. Really a great points this morning on this.

I want to turn to immigration because President Trump's administration is considering an executive order that would take a closer look at visa programs for foreign workers in the U.S. This according to "The Wall Street Journal" this morning.

Morgan, your take on this. For Trump, it would be another promise fulfilled in keeping jobs in America, frankly.

ORTAGUS: I would like -- first of all, clearly, our immigration system needs reform. I think people on both sides of the aisles are honest with themselves. What I would like prefer to see over an executive order is that the president work with congress on comprehensive reform. And the reason is that President Obama have seen this firsthand.

When you issue all of these executive orders, they can easily be done. And so one of the problems over the past eight years, one of the reason President Obama was not effective is because he didn't work with congress to push this legislation through.

So I like the idea of this. I think we need reform. I would like them to see him go to congress, get a comprehensive play. Get something codified and delude that can't be undone the minute the next president comes in.

MCDOWELL: The tech industry particularly is upset about this, about the going after the H-1B visas for highly skilled workers.

And I would argue on the other hand of that. In fact, the CEO of GoDaddy was writing that there are currently 500,000 unfilled high skilled I.T. in computer science jobs.

If you want American companies to create more jobs, then you want the best and brightest minds from around the world living here and creating ideas and products that are then American-owned. So I would argue that this is critical importance.

We need to reform the education system quite frankly if you want Americans to fill this jobs. In the interim, you want to support great American businesses.

BARTIROMO: Which is why those CEOs of those technology companies are putting together a letter to send to President Trump to obviously review everything you just said, having the crux of the issue.

KIERNAN: I think they want it so bad. About a million people immigrate here every year. I think we should take 50,000 or 60,000 of those H-1B visas and sell them for $50,000. And if the high-tech companies want those people so bad to fill those slots, sell them. We could raise a billion dollars a year, do that for five years. That's how you find your fixing of the education system. I think there's an opportunity --

BARTIROMO: How are you going to sell them though? Are you getting best students in that way?

KIERNAN: I think what you do as I say, we're going to give you a slot. We'll sell to you for $50,000. If you want one of those H-1 visas, you pay.

BARTIROMO: Wow. OK.

KIERNAN: For 50,000. We still have a million people coming in here with free of charge, no issue. But if we're going to turn this into a commercial partnership, let's really do it.

ORTAGUS: This is certainly be a discussion tomorrow with the president because he has CEOs that he's put on in his Business Roundtable that are meeting with him tomorrow. It's reported, I think that Elon Musk and the Uber CEO among others will be at the meeting. So I know that this will be --

MCDOWELL: Sadly not the Americans living here to fill these highly skilled jobs.

BARTIROMO: Well, that goes back to education because they don't have the skillsets required.

Meanwhile, President Trump tweeted this last night about his predecessor's decision to take in refugees from Australia. He writes this. Do you believe it? The Obama administration agreed to take thousands of illegal immigrants from Australia. Why? I will study this dumb deal."

This coming after Trump reportedly clashed with the Prime Minister of Australia. Malcom Turnbull last night during a phone call about this matter, calling it, "the worst deal ever."

He accused Turnbull of looking to export the next Boston bombers. Now, there's a lot of media reporting about this morning, Peter, that they had a tense call. Do you predict this change in the U.S. relationship with Australia? And how important was this call? And how impacts --

KIERNAN: Well I think it was cable setting. We're basically getting started, but have you been to Australia? I mean, there's plenty of rooms to take a few thousand --

BARTIROMO: They won't take them, by the way.

KIERNAN: And the problem is why are they dishing their problem to us? I think it was very right and appropriate for the president to say, we're going to level set. The relationship now has changed.

MCDOWELL: Or do it as a dumb deal.

BARTIROMO: I know.

ORTAGUS: The call happened on Saturday too and that was after the rollout of the executive order would bungled. I think even the administration has acknowledged that.

So he's probably on edge given the fact that it's been a rough weekend.

But the one thing that we have to say is the Australian prime minister reiterated the special relationship. We work incredibly closely with the Australians. Anytime we go to war and in intelligence matters. It's an important relationship.

MCDOWELL: These refugees are in offshore detention centers right now in Australia. And if it's a deal that President Obama inked with Australia, it's up to the new president to decide whether it's in our best interest.

BARTIROMO: Do we know when that deal was inked? Remember, President Obama was doing so much in the final twilight days of his administration? We'll get the answer for you.

We'll take a short break. When we come back, rumors in retail. The long time CEO of Macy's is stepping down. Now there's talk the struggling retailer may put itself up for sale. Macy's on sale.

And then this little piggy had none. Bacon lovers fearing a shortage of their favorite pork product. Why a price hike might be in store. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Two staffers are being held hostage at a Delaware maximum-security prison this morning. Lauren Simonetti on headlines now. Lauren, good morning to you.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi. Good morning, Maria. Two Delaware department of correction employees have been held hostage since last night, as inmates remained in an hour's long standoff with police.

This incident began when four employees at the correctional center were taken hostage yesterday morning. One DOC staff member was released four hours later, another shortly before 8:00 P. M.

In a call to the News Journal in Wilmington, one inmate reportedly cited President Donald Trump as the reason for the hostage situation saying because of Trump, he quote, "knows the institution is going to change for the worse."

Well, an attorney representing state inmates says complaints have increased in the past year from inmates about substandard medical care in poor record-keeping.

Big news in business world. A reported sale from Macy's is on the table. Longtime CEO Terry Lundgren stepping down as the head of the largest U. S. department store within the next few months. That's the report.

In an attempt to avoid more shakeup, Lundgren is reportedly considering a sale of Macy's. Macy's share in the past year are down about 30 percent. But this morning if you check out this board, they're up about four percent on the news.

And Nielsen mobile insights ranks T-Mobile number one in customer service satisfaction. The company beating up Verizon and AT&T as the company to most likely be recommended as well. This comes after T-Mobile offers to covers sales tax on new smartphones.

The deal will give customers more than 11 percent off of a phone's price if they're using a prepaid MasterCard.

All right. I love this story because I love to look at the video. For bacon lovers out there. Reports of frozen pork belly inventories reaching their lowest level in 50 years. Rest assured.

Earlier this week, we had a story that that was going to happen. But claims of these bacon shortages are unsupported. Meat processors are however paying 30 percent more than they did just a few months ago and that increase might show up shortly at supermarkets.

But for now, bacon prices are holding steady. And the USDA reports a pound of bacon averages actually 11 percent less than they did just back in 2015, Maria. So there you have it. Good morning and that's hogwash.

BARTIROMO: I like it. I'm glad you got dead end.

Breaking news right now, Lauren. We want to show everybody what Donald Trump has been tweeting. The president just tweeted this moments ago. If UC Berkeley does not allow free speech and practices violence on innocent people with a different point of view, no federal funds?"

Wow, the president is pretty aggressive in terms of coming out and saying, look, there are consequences for what you're doing. No federal funding?

MCDOWELL: I think that President Trump was watching Fox and Friends first this morning because Todd Starnes was on and had like a one-minute, two- minute commentary. That's exactly what Todd Starnes said on Fox and Friends first roughly an hour ago.

So I'm not saying that the president is getting his ideas from Mr. Starnes, but it's exactly what Todd was talking about.

BARTIROMO: This is a big issue though. How much money are we talking about in terms of what the federal government could hold back for university? We don't have those numbers.

ORTAGUS: When you at the pictures that you're showing of the protest, it looks pretty violent. So I think that Berkeley would argue. We cancel that to keep the students safe. Because it's incredibly violent. You saw fires and just watch it for yourself.

BARTIROMO: How does he get that out of control? Where is the leadership to stop it from getting out of control and putting things on fire at a university?

KIERNAN: Yes. I think it could become a lot calmer. If you look at how UC Davis handle it, they just canceled it. That's a better way to go

BARTIROMO: When we come back, what is in a name? How Elon Musk is rebranding Tesla motors after closing a new deal.

And then we've got an eye on earnings this morning. Facebook beating expectations last night. Wall Street's looking for Amazon to deliver next. We've got the growth story on Amazon coming up. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets looking lower this morning. But Facebook certainly one to watch. Take a look at the shares this morning. The company reporting a strong fourth quarter last night, easily topping analysts' expectations.

Company's revenue up a staggering 51 percent year-over-year in the quarter. It was not all good news for the company though. Jury sided against his Oculus brand in a lawsuit ordering it to pay $500 million to game maker ZeniMax.

Joining us "Wall Street Journal" chief economic correspondent, Jon Hilsenrath on that. Jon, good morning to you.

JON HILSENRATH, CHIEF ECONOMIC CORRESPONDENT, WALL STREET JOURNAL: Good morning, Maria. It's all about tech yesterday and today. We've got Amazon coming up later. And it looks like they're going to pump out blowout numbers too.

It's amazing to me that you have companies like Facebook and Amazon which are such a huge scale already. Amazon with almost 1.9 billion users around the world and it's pumping out 51 percent revenue growth numbers. To be that big and growing that fast is just really transformative.

BARTIROMO: You're right. And we're talking about Amazon a lot because it is incredibly successful. Look at the stock today and look at the business getting into all different industries. What do you think, Peter?

KIERNAN: Well, it's interesting, isn't it? That the very month that Amazon takes over from Macy's as the number one seller of apparel, there's a changing in the guard there.

And the thing that strikes me is Amazon went public exactly 20 years ago and that stock is up 42,000 percent.

BARTIROMO: Since the IPO?

KIERNAN: So if you put $1,000 in, it would be $420,000 today. It's been an extraordinary company way beyond e-tailing. And the thing I saw in a research report recently that I like is, somebody said it's a great company and by the way, it does not compete with Amazon.

So it's becoming a benefit not to be in a competitive view of Amazon.

HILSENRATH: It reminds me a lot of Wal-Mart in the night 1990s and that Wal-Mart wasn't just a retailer. It became a logistics powerhouse. The way it dealt its warehousing networks and technology to move products. That's what Amazon is really leading the show right now. They're investing so much in robotics, in warehousing and getting products to people overnight.

They're more than just a retailer. They're really at the vanguard of logistics information

MCDOWELL: I want to point out that Wal-Mart actually just rolled out a free shipping program for every single order and you don't have to like pay a subscription fee. Minimum $35 purchase but free two-day shipping to anybody in the United States.

So Wal-Mart has enough at least on the retail side to try and compete with Amazon. Maybe not the apparel selection, but they're even focused on that. You saw that over the holidays.

BARTIROMO: They've got to come up with things like free shipping. They're on their heels because Amazon is -- and we didn't even talk about original content. Those are competing but with movie company.

KIERNAN: They're behind Manchester by the Sea and some of the Academy award nominations. And so they are really looking at this world in a very broad gauge.

BARTIROMO: Incredible. Jon Hilsenrath, let me ask you. Any thoughts from the fed meeting and what you heard from Janet Yellen yesterday? And I want to ask you about this meeting with the president on Friday. Several CEOs headed to the White House tomorrow. JP Morgan CEO Jamie Dimon among them. Bob Iger, Walt Disney, Dr. Toby Cosgrove, as well CEO of IBM Ginni Rometty and Larry Fink from BlackRock. What do you expecting?

HILSENRATH: Well, on the fed meeting, they're in a wait-and-see mode. And what I find most interesting and what I've been debating with colleagues about for the last few days is whether the fed is on a collision course with Donald Trump.

Janet Yellen thinks that we're going to have around two percent growth over the next few years. Donald Trump wants four percent growth.

Now, if we get this faster growth is the fed get accommodated? As far as what the fed does next, I think really a lot depends on the jobs numbers. We're going to get pretty good wage growth numbers on jobs on Friday and that could keep the -- move the fed towards its next rate increase.

BARTIROMO: Yes, we got a great number, that's for sure.

HILSENRATH: The CEO meeting, this president has made a lot of promises that he's going cut back regulation and that he's going to achieve tax reform.

And I think the market has been very excited about that. At some point this year we have to see whether he delivers. One of the things you have to think about what this whole visa debate and immigration that's going on right now, that's more regulation, it's not less regulation. I wonder what kind of pushback he's going to get from the CEO meeting on that point.

BARTIROMO: That's probably the ones taking points for sure. Real quick, Peter.

KIERNAN: The one thing that I think is you predicted accurately. I think there's going to be a war. It's coming between Yellen and Trump. She sees growth at one-way, he sees another, inflation is coming. It's going to be over the dollars that they fight and it's right around the corner.

BARTIROMO: All right. Jon Hilsenrath, good to see you, sir. Thank you. We will see you soon.

HILSENRATH: All right. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, former chief executive of ExxonMobil, Rex Tillerson sworn in as secretary of state yesterday. But education secretary nominee Betsy DeVos still facing roadblocks. We'll get into it next.

And then striking gold. How a man from Kansas won Super Bowl tickets for life. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Thursday morning, everybody. Welcome back. We're happy you're with us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Thursday, February 2. Your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

President Trump's cabinet finally gaining another member -- Rex Tillerson sworn in as the next secretary of state yesterday after he was approved by the Senate in a 56 to 43 vote.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: This is where you were meant to be, right here today, at this crossroads in history. It's time to bring a clear-eyed focus to foreign affairs, to take a fresh look at the world around us and to seek new solutions grounded in very ancient truths.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The very latest on the continuing confirmations coming up this morning. President Trump honors a hero yesterday making an unannounced trip to receive the remains of the first service member lost during his presidency.

He went with his daughter, Ivanka Trump. The president just tweeting moments ago, "Attending Chief Ryan Owens' dignified transfer with my daughter, Ivanka, was my great honor. To a great and brave man, thank you."
